column1: When Angel Amankwaah traveled from Denver to North Carolina Central University for incoming student orientation this summer
column2: she decided she had made the right choice.

column1: She had fun learning the chants that fans perform at football games. But she also saw that “there are students who look like me
column2: and professors who look like me” at the historically Black university
column3: said Amankwaah
column5: who is Black. “I knew that I was in a safe space.”

column1: This has in the past two years become an important consideration for college-bound students from all backgrounds and beliefs. With so much attention focused on these issues
column2: USA TODAY and The Hechinger Report present the first-of-its-kind College Welcome Guide showing state laws and institutional policies that affect college and university students
column3: from bans on diversity
column4: equity and inclusion initiatives and “critical race theory” to rules about guns on campus and whether student IDs are accepted as proof of residency for voting purposes.

column1: The digital tables also list
column2: for every four-year institution in the country
column3: such things as racial and gender diversity among students and faculty
column4: the number of student veterans enrolled
column5: the incidence of on-campus race-motivated hate crimes
column6: free-speech rankings and if the university or college serves many students from rural places.

column1: Test our new College Welcome Guide:These tools offer a new lens on campus life.
Students have long picked schools based on their academic reputations and social life. But with campuses in the crosshairs of the culture wars
column2: many students are now also taking stock of attacks on diversity
column3: course content and speech and speakers from both ends of the political spectrum. They’re monitoring hate crimes
column4: anti-LGBTQ+ legislation
column5: state abortion laws and whether students like them ‒ Black
column6: rural
column7: military veterans
column8: LGBTQ+ or from other backgrounds ‒ are represented and supported on campus.

column1: “There’s no question that what’s happening at the state level is directly affecting these students
column2: ” said Alyse Levine
column3: founder and CEO of Premium Prep
column4: a private college admissions consulting firm in Chapel Hill
column5: North Carolina. When they look at colleges in various states now
column6: she said
column7: “There are students who are asking
column8: ‘Am I really wanted here?’”

column1: For some students on both sides of the political divide
column2: the answer is no. In the chaotic new world of American colleges and universities
column3: many say they feel unwelcome at certain schools
column4: while others are prepared to shut down speakers and report faculty with whose opinions they disagree.

column1: It’s too early to know how much this trend will affect where and whether prospective students end up going to college since publicly available enrollment data lags real time. But there are early clues that it’s having a significant impact.
One in 4 prospective students has already ruled out a college or university for consideration because of the political climate in its state
column2: according to a survey by the higher education consulting firm Art & Science Group.

column1: Among students who describe themselves as liberal
column2: the most common reason to rule out colleges and universities in a particular state
column3: that survey found
column4: is because it’s “too Republican” or has what they consider lax gun regulations
column5: anti-LGBTQ+ legislation
column6: restrictive abortion laws and a lack of concern about racism. Students who describe themselves as conservative are rejecting states they believe to be “too Democrat” and that have liberal abortion and gay rights laws.

column1: Sixty percent of prospective students of all backgrounds say new state restrictions on abortion would at least somewhat influence where they choose to go to college
column2: a separate poll by Gallup and the Lumina Foundation found. Of these
column3: 8 in 10 say they would prefer to go to a state with greater access to reproductive health services. (Lumina is among the funders of The Hechinger Report
column4: which produced this story.)

column1: “We have many young women who will not look at certain states
column2: ” said Levine. One of her own clients backed out of going to a university in St. Louis after Missouri banned almost all abortions following the Supreme Court’s Dobbs decision
column3: she said.

column1: Institutions in Alabama
column2: Florida
column3: Louisiana and Texas are the most likely to be knocked off the lists of liberal students
column4: according to the Art & Science Group survey. They’re generally most likely to steer clear of the South and Midwest
column5: while conservative students avoid California and New York.

column1: One in 8 high school students in Florida say they won’t go to a public university in their own state because of its education policies
column2: a separate poll
column3: by the college ranking and information website Intelligent.com
column4: found.

column1: With 494 anti-LGBTQ+ laws proposed or adopted this year
column2: according to the American Civil Liberties Union
column3: prospective students who are LGBTQ+ and have experienced significant harassment because of it are nearly twice as likely to say they don't plan to go to college at all compared with students who experienced lower levels of harassment
column4: according to a survey by GLSEN
column5: formerly the Gay
column6: Lesbian and Straight Education Network.

column1: “You are attacking kids who are already vulnerable
column2: ” said Javier Gomez
column3: an LGBTQ+ student in his first year at Miami Dade College. “And it’s not just queer students. So many young people are fed up.”

column1: It’s not yet evident whether the new laws are affecting where LGBTQ+ young people are choosing to go to college
column2: said Casey Pick
column3: director of law and policy at The Trevor Project
column4: which supports LGBTQ+ young people in crisis. But LGBTQ+ adults are moving away from states passing anti-LGBTQ+ laws
column5: she said. And “if adult employees are taking this into account when they decide where they want to live
column6: you can bet that college students are making the same decisions.”

column1: Since DeSantis takeover
column2: surge in dropouts at New College of Florida

column1: Meanwhile
column2: in an era of pushback against diversity
column3: equity and inclusion policies in many states
column4: and against affirmative action in college admissions nationwide
column5: Amankwaah is one of a growing number of Black students choosing what they see as the relative security of an HBCU. Enrollment at HBCUs increased by around 3% in 2021
column6: the last year for which the figure is available
column7: while the number of students at other universities and colleges fell.

column1: “The real attack here is on the feeling of belonging
column2: ” said Jeremy Young
column3: who directs the Freedom to Learn program at PEN America
column4: which tracks laws that restrict college and university diversity efforts and teaching about race. “What it really does is hoist a flag to say to the most marginalized students
column5: ‘We don’t want you here.’”

column1: More than 40% of university and college administrators say the Supreme Court ruling curbing the use of affirmative action in admissions will affect diversity on their campuses
column2: a Princeton Review poll found as the school year was beginning.

column1: College students of all races and political persuasions report feeling uncomfortable on campuses that have become political battlegrounds. Those on the left are bristling at new laws blocking programs in diversity
column2: equity and inclusion and the teaching of certain perspectives about race; on the right
column3: at conservative speakers being shouted down or canceled
column4: unpopular comments being called out in class and what they see as an embrace of values different from what they learned at home.

column1: More than 1 in 10 students at four-year universities now say they feel as if they downright don’t belong on their campus
column2: and another 2 in 10 neither agree nor strongly agree that they belong
column3: another Lumina and Gallup survey found. It found that those who answer in these ways are more likely to frequently experience stress and more likely to drop out.

column1: Military veterans who use their GI Bill benefits to return to school say one of their most significant barriers is a feeling that they won’t be welcome
column2: a survey by the D’Aniello Institute for Veterans and Military Families at Syracuse University found. Nearly two-thirds say that faculty and administrators don’t understand the challenges they face
column3: and 70% say the same thing about their non-veteran classmates.

column1: Colleges should be “safe and affirming spaces
column2: ” said Pick
column3: of the Trevor Project ‒ not places of isolation and alienation.

column1: Yet a significant number of students say they don’t feel comfortable sharing their views in class
column2: according to another survey
column3: conducted by College Pulse for the right-leaning Sheila and Robert Challey Institute for Global Innovation and Growth at North Dakota State University. Of those
column4: 72% say they worry their opinions would be considered unacceptable by classmates and 45%
column5: by their professors. Conservative students are less likely than their liberal classmates to believe that all points of view are welcome and less willing to share theirs.

column1: “Is that really an intellectually diverse environment?” asked Sean Stevens
column2: director of polling and analytics at the Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression
column3: or FIRE
column4: which has launched a campus free-speech ranking based on students’ perceptions of comfort expressing ideas
column5: tolerance for speakers and other measures.

column1: “Anecdotally and from personal experience
column2: there’s certainly a pocket of students who are weighing these factors in terms of where to go to college
column3: ” Stevens said.

column1: Eighty-one percent of liberal students and 53% of conservative ones say they support reporting faculty who make comments that they find offensive
column2: the same survey found. It used sample comments such as
column3: “There is no evidence of anti-Black bias in police shootings
column4: ” “Requiring vaccination for COVID is an assault on individual freedom” and “Biological sex is a scientific fact.”

column1: A professor at Texas A&M University became the subject of an investigation when a student accused her of criticizing the state’s lieutenant governor during a lecture
column2: though she was ultimately exonerated. An anthropology lecturer at the University of Chicago who taught an undergraduate course called “The Problem of Whiteness” said she was deluged with hateful messages when a conservative student posted her photo and email address on social media.

column1: More than half of all freshmen say that colleges have the right to ban extreme speakers
column2: according to an annual survey by an institute at the University of California
column3: Los Angeles; the College Pulse poll says that sentiment is held by twice the proportion of liberal students as conservative ones.

column1: A group of Stanford students in March disrupted an on-campus speech by a federal judge whose judicial record they said was anti-LGBTQ+. When he asked for an administrator to intervene
column2: an associate dean for diversity
column3: equity and inclusion confronted him and asked: “Is it worth the pain that this causes and the division that this causes?” The associate dean was put on leave and later resigned.

column1: “Today it is a sad fact that the greatest threat to free speech comes from within the academy
column2: ” pronounced the right-leaning American Council of Trustees and Alumni
column3: which is pushing colleges to sign on to its Campus Freedom Initiative that encourages teaching students about free expression during freshman orientation and disciplining people who disrupt speakers or events
column4: among other measures.

column1: “I have to imagine that universities that have a bad track record on freedom of expression or academic freedom
column2: that it will affect their reputations
column3: ” said Steven Maguire
column4: the organization’s campus freedom fellow. “I do hear people saying things like
column5: ‘I’m worried about what kind of a college or university I can send my kids to and whether they’ll be free to be themselves and to express themselves.’”

column1: Some colleges are now actively recruiting students on the basis of these kinds of concerns. Colorado College in September created a program to ease the process for students who want to transfer away from institutions in states that have banned diversity
column2: equity and inclusion initiatives; Hampshire College in Massachusetts has offered admission to any student from New College in Florida
column3: subject of what critics have described as a conservative takeover. Thirty-five have so far accepted the invitation.

column1: Though many conservative critics of colleges and universities say faculty are indoctrinating students with liberal opinions
column2: incoming freshmen tend to hold left-leaning views before they ever set foot in a classroom
column3: according to that UCLA survey.

column1: Fewer than 1 in 5 consider themselves conservative. Three-quarters say abortion should be legal and favor stricter gun control laws
column2: 68% say wealthy people should pay more taxes than they do now and 86% that climate change should be a federal priority and that there should be a clear path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants.

column1: Prospective students say they are watching as new laws are passed and controversies erupt on campuses and actively looking into not just the quality of food and available majors at the colleges they might attend
column2: but state politics.

column1: “Once I decided I was going to North Carolina Central
column2: I looked up whether North Carolina was a red state or a blue state
column3: ” Amankwaah said. (North Carolina has a Democrat as governor but Republicans control both chambers of the legislature and hold a veto-proof supermajority in the state Senate.

column1: Florida’s anti-LGBTQ+ laws prompted Javier Gomez to leave his native state and move to New York to go to fashion school. But then he came back
column2: transferring to Miami Dade.

column1: “People ask me
column2: ‘Why the hell are you back in Florida?’” said Gomez. “The reason I came back was that there was this innate calling in me that you have to stick around and fight for the queer and trans kids here. It’s overwhelming at times. It can be very mentally depleting. But I wanted to stay and continue the fight and build community against hatred.”

column1: This story about choosing colleges was produced by The Hechinger Report
column2: a nonprofit
column3: independent news organization focused on inequality and innovation in education. Sign up for our higher education newsletter.

column1: Thousands of Israelis and Palestinians have been killed and Palestinians have been ordered to evacuate from the northern Gaza Strip ahead of Israel's impending ground invasion
column2: leading to a humanitarian crisis that has brought protests from the United Nations and around the world.

column1: The U.N. said about 1 million Gaza residents have been displaced in just a week
column2: about half of them finding refuge in U.N. schools and other facilities where water supplies are diminishing. The war has claimed more than 4
column3: 000 lives since Hamas launched an unprecedented surprise attack Oct. 7.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: the World Health Organization pleaded with Israel on Sunday to immediately reverse evacuation orders for hospitals in northern Gaza
column3: saying the deadlines are impossible to meet and risk additional loss of life. WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus warned that attacks on health care facilities are already causing deaths and injuries.

column1: The health situation in north Gaza is dire, Tedros wrote on social media. "Evacuation orders by Israel to hospitals are practically impossible to implement and are a death sentence for the sick and injured."
Here are several organizations that are providing aid to people caught in the conflict.
How to cope:The videos out of Israel
column2: Gaza are graphic
column3: but some can't look away

column1: The Alliance for Middle East Peace (ALLMEP) is a coalition of more than 170 nongovernmental organizations that includes tens of thousands of Palestinians and Israelis who share the goal of building peace between the two communities.

Our members are speaking loudly and clearly about the values that unite our community: Opposition to this horrific violence, and a commitment to Israeli/Palestinian partnership on the path to ending it, and achieving peace and equality, the agency said in a statement.

The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) is a humanitarian organization that aims to protect and aid victims of conflicts. The ICRC has been in Israel and the occupied territories since 1967. The organization is asking for donations to improve access to essential services like water and to support livelihood projects.
Doctors Without Borders is a nongovernmental organization that describes itself as an "independent
column2: impartial and neutral" charity that provides humanitarian aid to people affected by conflict
column3: disease outbreaks and natural and human-made disasters.

column1: The agency is seeking donations to continue to provide medical care in the area. The agency has reported overcrowding in hospitals
column2: a lack of medical supplies
column3: and dangerous working conditions as it tries to support the thousands injured by the fighting.

column1: UNRWA has designated shelters to host the estimated 127
column2: 000 people displaced in Gaza. The agency is seeking donations to support its work.

column1: The Jewish Agency for Israel North American Council
column2: an American charity organization
column3: is accepting donations to help victims of terrorism.

column1: Save the Children issued an emergency alert in response to the conflict
column2: noting that escalating violence has left 1.2 million children in need of humanitarian aid. The agency is accepting donations.

column1: National and international organizations that aid victims in the conflict include the Palestine Children's Relief Fund (PCRF)
column2: which works to provide lifesaving medical relief and humanitarian aid.

column1: Founded by former President Jimmy Carter and his wife
column2: Rosalynn Carter
column3: in partnership with Emory University
column4: The Carter Center is a humanitarian aid organization that has been promoting peace and a viable two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict for decades.

column1: After Israel declared war
column2: The Carter Center released a statement condemning the targeting of Israeli and Palestinian civilians and called for international action to end the violence.

column1: Contributing: Julie Garisto
column2: Leesburg Daily Commercial; The Associated Press

column1: The soap opera that has consumed members of Congress for nearly three weeks over electing a new speaker is testing the patience of the voters who sent them to Washington
column2: a new USA TODAY/Suffolk University Poll finds.

column1: An overwhelming 67% say the House should elect a speaker as soon as possible
column2: given the need to approve wartime aid for Israel and Ukraine and to prevent a government shutdown that looms next month.

column1: We got to have a speaker, (but) I don't think we're going to have anybody soon, said George Ramge
column3: of San Diego
column4: a building contractor and political independent. "There's a lot of Hollywood politicians out there getting their time on TV
column5: and I don't think they're really serving the people's purpose."

column1: They need to be functioning, and that's the only way they're going to function, said Carl Hickey
column3: of Monkton
column4: Maryland
column5: a retired Methodist minister and a Democrat
column6: said in a follow-up interview after being called in the poll.

column1: Just 25% of those surveyed say they don't care whether a speaker is elected
column2: on the theory that the impasse is preventing Congress from wasting more taxpayer money.

column1: It's not like they do anything anyways, said Dustin Gibbons
column3: a home warranty manager from Queen Creek
column4: Arizona
column5: and a Republican. "I don't think that a speaker in the House is going to do anything other than
column6: you know
column7: just keep kicking that ball along."

column1: The poll of 1
column2: 000 registered voters
column3: taken by landline and cell phone Tuesday through Friday
column4: has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.1 percentage points.

column1: In a political world where bipartisanship is the exception
column2: there is a broad consensus on this. By double-digit margins
column3: the idea of electing a speaker
column4: and fast
column5: was endorsed not only among Democrats (86%-10%) but also Republicans (57%-34%) and independents (59%-32%).

column1: How often do you see Democrats, Republicans, and independents agree on anything in DC? said David Paleologos
column2: director of Suffolk's Political Research Center. "Look at every demographic: gender
column3: geography
column4: age
column5: race
column6: education level
column7: income
column8: political philosophy
column9: even those who trust CNN vs Fox News. They are all speaking the same seven words in unison: 'Elect a speaker and do your job.'"

column1: The previous House speaker
column2: Rep. Kevin McCarthy
column3: R-Calif.
column4: was ousted from the post by a handful of combative conservatives
column5: just eight of them but enough given the GOP's narrow majority. Since then
column6: no potential successor has been able to command the 217 votes needed. Ohio congressman Jim Jordan was defeated three times before the Republican caucus voted Friday to sideline him.

column1: House Republicans are scheduled to meet late Monday to figure out what to do next.

The scenes of Capitol chaos displayed on cable TV last week may be eroding voters' confidence in the ability of the nation's leaders in the White House and Congress to address the nation's major challenges.
Just 4% of those surveyed express "a lot" of confidence in leaders; another 32% had "some" confidence. But the largest group
column3: have "very little" confidence and another 27% had none at all.

column1: If I could go negative five, I would give it a negative 100, Gibbons said.
Democrats
column2: who traditionally have supported a bigger role for government
column3: have more confidence in its ability to solve problems; 63% had "a lot" or "some" confidence.

column1: But Republicans
column2: whose leaders in recent years have portrayed the government as either incompetent or dangerous
column3: were overwhelmingly skeptical that Washington could be trusted to do anything right. A plurality of Republicans
column5: said they had no confidence in government; another 38% had "very little."

column1: Ratings for the Senate are nothing to brag about
column2: with 36% having a favorable view
column3: and 42% an unfavorable one.

column1: But ratings for the House are even worse. Just 25% see it favorably; more than double that
column3: view it unfavorably.

column1: Once there is a speaker
column2: most voters have a suggestion of what they want them to do next: A compromise that avoids a government shutdown when the latest temporary funding bill expires Nov. 17.

column1: More than six in 10
column3: want negotiations to reach a deal. "I mean
column4: don't we live in a bipartisan world?" said Desiree Whitney
column6: of Boerne
column7: Texas
column8: an independent who voted for former President Donald Trump in 2020. "Why should it stop
column9: you know at our government
column10: or does it begin there? I mean

column1: But there's a catch. While just 31% want their representatives to stand firm on demands to cut spending
column2: even if it means a government shutdown
column3: that group includes a 55% majority of Republicans. Only 37% in the GOP endorse a negotiated compromise.

column1: And Republicans control what happens in the House − assuming
column2: of course
column3: they succeed in electing a speaker.

column1: Gymnast Kara Eaker announced Friday on Instagram her retirement from the University of Utah women’s gymnastics team and withdrawal as a student
column2: citing verbal and emotional abuse from a coach and lack of support from the administration.

column1: “For two years
column2: while training with the Utah Gymnastics team
column3: I was a victim of verbal and emotional abuse
column4: ” Eaker wrote in a post. “As a result
column5: my physical
column6: mental and emotional health has rapidly declined. I had been seeing a university athletics psychologist for a year and a half and I’m now seeing a new provider twice a week because of suicidal and self-harm ideation and being unable to care for myself properly. I have recently been diagnosed with severe anxiety and depression
column7: anxiety induced insomnia
column8: and I suffer from panic attacks
column9: PTSD and night terrors. …

column1: “I have now reached a turning point and I’m speaking out for all of the women who can’t because they are mentally debilitated and paralyzed by fear.”
Eaker
column3: is an elite American gymnast who was part of U.S. gold-medal teams at the 2018 and 2019 world championships. She was named an alternate at the Tokyo Olympics in 2021 and was a member of Utah’s teams that finished third at the NCAA championships in 2022 and 2023. Utah is one of the top programs in women’s college gymnastics.

column1: USA TODAY Sports has reached out to the University of Utah for comment.
“I was a promised a ‘family’ within this program and a ‘sisterhood’ with my teammates
column2: who would accept me
column3: care for me
column4: and support
column5: ” Eaker wrote. “But instead
column6: as I entered as a freshman
column7: I was heartbroken to find the opposite in that I was training in an unhealthy
column8: unsafe and toxic environment."

column1: She alleged “loud and angry outbursts” that involved cursing from a coach.
Eaker said the abuse “often happened in individual coach-athlete meetings. I would be isolated in an office with an overpowering coach
column2: door closed
column3: sitting quietly
column4: hardly able to speak because of the condescending
column5: sarcastic and manipulative tactics."

column1: When Eaker went to university officials with her allegations
column2: she wrote
column3: "One administrator denied there was any abuse and said
column4: 'You two are like oil and water
column5: you just don't get along.' To say I was shocked would be an understatement and this is a prime example of gaslighting. So therein lies the problem − the surrounding people and system are complicit."

column1: Eaker does not name any coach in her post. Tom Farden has been coaching at Utah since 2011
column2: a co-head coach from 2016-2019 and sole head coach from 2020. Last month
column3: an investigation into Farden by Husch Blackwell concluded Farden
column4: “did not engage in any severe
column5: pervasive or egregious acts of emotional or verbal abuse of student-athletes” and “did not engage in any acts of physical abuse
column6: emotional abuse or harassment as defined by SafeSport Code.”

column1: However
column2: the investigation found Farden “made a derogatory comment to a student-athlete that if she was not at the University she would be a ‘nobody working at a gas station’ in her hometown” and “a few student-athletes alleged that Coach Farden made comments to student-athletes that
column3: if corroborated
column4: would have likely resulted in a finding that they violated the Athletics’ Well Being Policy’s prohibition on degrading language. The comments as alleged were isolated occurrences that could not be independently corroborated and were denied by Coach Farden.”

column1: In her Instagram post
column2: Eaker called the investigation “incomplete at best
column3: and I disagree with their findings. I don’t believe it has credibility because the report omits crucial evidence and information and the few descriptions used are inaccurate.”

column1: It's well known that having obesity increases the risk of a wide range of health conditions
column2: but data suggests it may not be just the extra weight that adds risk.

column1: Medications may not work as well on people with obesity
column2: studies suggest
column3: because
column4: although people with a lot of body fat metabolize drugs differently
column5: they aren't required to be included in research trials. So prescribed doses may be too high in some cases and linger too long in others.

column1: And with more than 40% of Americans now living with obesity
column2: and a wide range of popular drugs potentially affected
column3: this dosing deficit is likely having a major impact on many people's lives and health
column4: several experts said.

column1: Studies have found people taking regular medication for birth control
column2: or to combat high cholesterol
column3: depression or panic disorders might be getting the wrong amount of needed medication.

column1: It's "a huge problem for the population
column2:
said Dr. William Dietz, who directs the STOP Obesity Alliance at George Washington University in Washington, D.C., and co-wrote a recent paper on the topic.
Dietz blames weight bias for the lack of attention to a major portion of the population. I think it's because people don't care about obesity."

column1: For Courtney Gilbert
column2: of Big Rapids
column3: Michigan
column4: the depression that overtook her in 2019 was deep and lingering and drugs simply weren't helping.

column1: I tried medication after medication after medication, said Gilbert
column2: who works for the local public library system. "This coming up does make me wonder if my weight had something to do with it."

column1: She eventually overcame her depression with therapy
column2: a strong support system
column3: more stability and the passage of time after a major loss.

column1: The dosage of antipsychotic medications
column2: like the one Gilbert took for months to no effect
column3: does not get altered by prescribing doctors based on a patient's weight. But body fat affects how quickly the body processes the antipsychotic brexpiprazole
column4: sold under the brand name Rexulti.

column1: Someone with a lot of body fat will process drugs like brexpiprazole more slowly than a person with less and will therefore need a higher dose to get the same benefit
column2: said Dr. Caroline Apovian
column3: an author of a poster on the drug trials and obesity presented this month at ObesityWeek 2023 in Dallas.

column1: The dosing and the pharmacokinetics all have to do with when and how much enters the bloodstream and it's in the bloodstream that the drugs have their effects, said Apovian
column2: who also co-directs the Center for Weight Management and Wellness at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston.

column1: If you don't test patients of size and you're dosing a drug based on the bloodstream entrance of patients with 'normal' body fat ‒ the doses for normal body weight might not be effective for those with obesity.
Medications also hang around a large body longer
column2: potentially causing side effects or interacting with other medications.

column1: But Apovian and her co-authors showed that more than half the drug trials underway do not mention body mass index in their official descriptions on clinicaltrials.gov.
When body mass
column2: a typical measure of obesity
column3: is mentioned
column4: it is generally used to exclude people with obesity from being in a trial altogether
column5: they found.

column1: It's nuts, said Ted Kyle
column2: another of the poster's authors
column3: who writes the blog ConscienHealth. "It's not like you have to do deep studies with every drug
column4: but at minimum
column5: we ought to be saying
column6: 'Oh
column7: would this be a problem?'"

column1: Regulators don't require that drugs be specifically tested in people with large amounts of body fat
column2: so even if doctors wanted to prescribe a higher dose
column3: they wouldn't know how much to give or which drugs were most likely affected
column4: Apovian and other experts said.

column1: The Food and Drug Administration
column2: which regulates drug approvals and sets requirements for drugs trials
column3: acknowledges the problem.

column1: FDA Commissioner Dr. Robert Califf
column2: speaking at a workshop a year ago
column3: said there's a "deficit of information" about how drugs affect people with obesity and that they're often underrepresented in research trials.

column1: He said he hoped workshop participants from FDA
column2: the University of Maryland and elsewhere would help close this information gap "to ensure that we're making progress toward appropriate drug dosing in the obese patient."

column1: People with obesity aren't necessarily excluded from clinical trials
column2: but they may be reluctant to participate because of poor experiences with the medical system. They may also be excluded because of other health issues they face
column3: such as high blood pressure or diabetes. Or it's possible that companies running the trials simply do not analyze obesity even as they consider sex
column4: age and race important factors.

column1: Regulators have said obesity adds to variability in trials
column2: which is why companies aren't required to include people with obesity at the outset. But Dietz
column3: from the STOP Obesity Alliance
column4: said that's precisely why they should be included.

column1: Also
column2: he said
column3: only half-jokingly
column4: he'd expect drug companies would want to identify patients who would benefit from a higher dose of medications because they could be charged more.

column1: Dr. Fatima Cody Stanford
column2: an obesity medicine specialist at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston
column3: praised the companies involved in COVID-19 vaccine trials for including a large percentage of people with obesity. If they could do it
column4: with the time pressure they were under
column5: then other companies can do it
column6: too
column7: she said.

column1: I'm not going to give them a pass on this, she said of other drug companies and trials. At least 40% of adults and 20% of children in clinical trials for all sorts of drugs
column2: not just those addressing obesity
column3: need to be of a higher body mass index
column4: she said.

column1: Cody Stanford said she's particularly disturbed by the lack of data for drugs like brexpiprazole
column2: which are intended for a population already facing a stigmatizing mental health condition.

column1: People with schizophrenia or depression are more likely to have obesity than the general population. One 2017 study found that 59% of people with schizophrenia had obesity. Drugs used to treat schizophrenia are known to increase body weight.

There are so many layers of badness that can happen here if it's not tested well and doesn't reach effective levels in people with obesity, she said. "This is a recipe for disaster in a condition that's not well understood
column2: even if it is well treated."

column1: Dietz and several colleagues published a paper in August showing that a number of commonly used drugs are fat soluble
column2: meaning they would take longer to reach an effective dose in the bloodstream of someone with a lot of body fat.

column1: The paper listed a number of common drugs its authors thought might be affected by a person's body size:
In another example provided in that study
column2: which appeared in the journal "Health Affairs
column3:
the anti-fungal drug posaconazole has a warning in its packaging that it might be ineffective in patients with obesity at the typical dosage. But there's no instruction about what the right dose might be. And because it lasts in the body of a larger person longer than in a person without obesity, it might interact with other drugs given at the same time.
If these drugs are not adjusted for the person's body fat they may be less effective or not effective at all, said Dietz, who also directs the Sumner M. Redstone Global Center for Prevention and Wellness at George Washington University's Milken Institute School of Public Health.
The provider's response might be
column4: 'Why aren't you taking the drug?' (They) blame the patient when in fact
column5: it's the pharmacodynamics that should be blamed."

column1: What Dietz wants is for every doctor who treats a patient with obesity to know if the drug they are prescribing is potentially affected by that patient's body weight. "It should be top-of-mind when writing a prescription
column2:
he said, though he admits it's unclear how to adjust drug dosage.
For her part, Gilbert said she naturally assumed because her medication had been prescribed by a doctor that it had been researched and dosed properly. Luckily, she got through her period of suicidal thinking without acting on it, but other people, given an ineffective dose, might not.
It's definitely something that (people need) to be made aware of so it doesn't keep happening
column3: she said. Starting with judgments or assumptions that we don't care that we're overweight or this is just a choice ‒ and that because we're overweight we don't deserve adequate medical care."

column1: If that is an assumption someone has
column2: Gilbert said. That's not okay."

Hamas – an acronym for Harakat al-Muqawama al-Islamiya, or the Islamic resistance movement – was founded in 1987 by activists connected to the Muslim Brotherhood during the first Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation of Gaza and the West Bank. The State Department designated Hamas a terrorist group in 1997, and several other nations also consider Hamas a terrorist organization.
In 2006, Hamas won parliamentary elections, and in 2007 the group violently seized control of Gaza from the Palestinian Authority, which was controlled by the rival Fatah movement that still governs the West Bank. There have been no elections since. The group calls for the establishment of an Islamic Palestinian state that would replace the current state of Israel and believes in the use of violence to carry out the destruction of Israel.
Hamas receives financial, material, and logistical support from Iran. So far, however, the U.S. and other nations have said there is no evidence that Iran was directly involved in Hamas’ attack.

column1: Famed sportscaster Jim Nantz offered golfers playing Pebble Beach a legendary opportunity
column2: offering to provide play-by-play for a group of golfers teeing off on the famously short seventh hole
column3: a 109-yard Par 3.

column1: The video was posted to the cameraman Jason Deaver's TikTok account
column2: @jdprogolf. Deaver is currently attempting to become a professional golfer. He holds a +2 handicap at the moment. The video was actually taken about a month and a half ago
column3: Deaver told USA Today. It was Deaver's first time at Pebble Beach
column4: and the group he was caddying for got VIP treatment.

column1: Worlds collide:Formula 1
column2: PGA Tour stars come together for "The Netflix Cup" live golf tournament

column1: According to Deaver
column2: Nantz was "showing the course to his friends from out of town" when he pulled up in his cart to the seventh tee. Nobody asked him to provide play-by-play either. That was entirely Nantz's idea.

column1: He said to me, 'Why don't you pull out your phone real quick? I want to do something,' said Deaver. "It kind of became an iconic little moment for everybody. Under that pressure
column2: I'm not sure I could put it on the green."

column1: The man who hit the green was another golfer that was put in Deaver's group
column2: David Lorenz. Regardless
column3: Nantz offered background commentary for multiple people in that group according to Deaver
column4: but only went full broadcaster mode for David's tee shot. That just so happened to be the best shot of the bunch. According to Deaver
column5: every other shot from the group failed to hit the green.

column1: I would say that was one of Lorenz's best shots of the day, Deaver claimed. "He had about two or three birdies that day
column2: so he didn't play terrible golf. I would probably say that was the shot of his life though." Deaver continued
column3: "He was totally on top of the world. He couldn't believe it."

column1: Even though Lorenz had the best shot of the bunch
column2: Deaver claimed that it was impossible to be upset after that interaction happened. Said Deaver
column3: "The rest of the day
column4: you can't get mad at anything after that happening
column5: you know?"

column1: While Deaver would not consider himself a friend or acquaintance of Nantz
column2: he told USA Today that he has met Nantz a few times before. "He's a great guy
column3: says Deaver, one of the nicest guys you could ever meet."

column1: Nantz's children play junior golf with Deaver's college golf coach. "I've met him a few times through that
column2: because I help out with that." Deaver explained further
column3: "So
column4: yeah
column5: I've seen him before
column6: and he's always been a really good human being and always taken his time to have a conversation with you when he doesn't have to."

column1: It costs around $600 for a single tee time at Pebble Beach. There are additional fees that come too though if you or anyone in your group wants a caddy or cart. That's a lot
column2: but Pebble Beach is regarded as one of the nicest courses in America. So
column3: this begs the question
column4: "How much more would you be willing to pay to have your entire round narrated by Jim Nantz?"

column1: I don't know if I'd pay a whole lot, said Deaver. "It'd be an awesome experience
column2: but my money right now goes to tournament golf. I would definitely think people would pay thousands and thousands of dollars to have that happen. I would think people would pay thousands just to hit that one shot."

column1: Deaver
column2: Lorenz
column3: and company got that opportunity for free
column4: an all-time cool move from Nantz.

column2: scores
column3: and leaderboards

column1: For the last four decades
column2: invasive Burmese python snakes have terrorized mammals and the greater ecosystem of the Everglades National Park and throughout South Florida.

column1: Now
column2: a recent study shows what is biting back.

column1: The Southeast Asian apex predator can grow up to 19 feet long
column2: weigh more than 150 pounds and eat everything from rabbits to deer. The pythons and their appetites are also blamed for the disappearance of almost all the fur-bearing mammals in the Everglades and surrounding areas.

column1: A new study by the U.S. Geological Survey and partner organizations in Florida studied the deaths of 19 baby Burmese pythons from May 2021 to February 2022 to see how this part of the python population might meet its fate.
Burmese pythons are difficult to track or monitor
column2: according to Mark Sandfoss
column3: Biologist at Fort Collins Science Center stationed in Everglades National Park. But studies like this provide data points to fill in the gaps of their life cycle.

column1: It takes a lot of time and effort to collect these data, Sandfoss said in an emailed statement to USA TODAY. "We need more information and are continuing to track juvenile pythons in Southern Florida to understand their ecology
column2: particularly movement
column3: habitat use
column4: and survival."

column1: Burmese pythons:Latest hunt netted over 200 of the invasive species in the Everglades
Burmese pythons are native to Southeast Asia. They were imported to Florida to be sold to pet owners
column2: and were likely released or escaped. They established a wild population in the 1980s
column3: according to the study
column4: and Sandfoss said they can grow to be 19 feet long and weigh more than 150 pounds.

column1: Since then
column2: they have wreaked havoc on the natural environment
column3: eating everything from rabbits to deer with few species being able to check the population. The USGS estimates there are tens of thousands living in the Everglades.

column1: A 2012 study showed that pythons' diets have drastically cut the populations of Everglades-area mammals. Raccoon
column2: opossum and bobcat populations had dropped 85%-99%
column3: and rabbits and foxes had "effectively disappeared."

column1: Humans may be one known predator of the python
column2: but the recent USGS study shows there are more
column3: at least for the babies.

column1: More:Florida will teach you how to hunt
column2: kill Burmese pythons. Practice and you could get paid

column1: Juvenile Burmese pythons were opportunistically collected throughout more than a year. They were implanted with high-frequency radio transmitters equipped with mortality sensors that notified researches when the snake stopped moving for 24 hours.
During the length of the study
column2: 19 baby snakes died. At that point
column3: scientists would go to the scene of the crime and conduct some detective work to discover the cause of death.

column1: Here is what they found:
Among the deceased juveniles recorded as part of the study
column2: one ambitious snake set a new record for pythons that size. It attempted to eat a hispid cotton rat that weighed 106% of the python's body weight.

column1: The study says this is notable in more ways than one. Its failure to accurately assess prey could be a sign of a maladaptive behaviors due to different prey sizes in the new environment compared to their native environment.
Maladaptive behaviors provide scientists the opportunity to identify potential weaknesses in an invasive species that have otherwise thrived in a new environment
column2: Sandfoss said. While maladaptive behaviors are naturally selected out of the population overtime
column3: the native species can also adapt to the invasive species in that time.

column1: Sandfoss said that
column2: given the wide range of prey that adult pythons eat
column3: scientists did no know if native species had learned to adapt to avoid becoming prey or even become a predator.

column1: He said that the range of predators they found in the study was a pleasant surprise. A cottonmouth snake
column2: for example
column3: would never be able to eat an adult python
column4: but did consume one of the juveniles in the study.

column1: Sandfoss also said that this data is part of a long journey to understand the Burmese python's life cycle in Florida to better aid their population mitigation strategies.
Our role as scientists is to try to tip the scales in the direction of the native species and identify the weaknesses of the invasive species that we can exploit for management purposes, he said.
Contributing: Amy Bennett Williams
column2: Naples Daily News; Kim Luciani
column3: Chad Gillis Fort Myers News-Press

column1: Spoiler alert! This story includes detailed plot points of the new movie "Killers of the Flower Moon" and the real-life events on which it's based.
The new Martin Scorsese movie “Killers of the Flower Moon” plays like an improbable human horror story
column2: brimming with deceit and death in 1920s Oklahoma.

column1: The 3-hour-and 26-minute film
column2: starring Robert De Niro
column3: Leonardo DiCaprio and Lily Gladstone
column4: tells the story of Osage Nation tribal members
column5: newly wealthy from the discovery of oil on their otherwise parched reservation lands
column6: and the duplicitous non-Native Americans who swoop in to steal their bounty.

column1: But while it plays like an allegory
column2: the story is true. Based on the best-selling 2017 book by journalist David Grann
column3: “Killers” is the result of years of research and interviews with Osage elders. The tale explored both the deaths surrounding the family of Mollie Burkhart (Gladstone) as well as the exploits of the nascent Federal Bureau of Investigation.

column1: USA TODAY spoke with Grann to get details on how the movie compares with his book.
“Absolutely
column2: ” says Grann. “Because of the vast oil deposits on their lands
column3: by the 1920s the Osage were among the wealthiest people per capita in the world.”

column1: People of the Osage Nation had been moved around by the federal government for years before winding up in a barren stretch of Oklahoma
column2: which wasn’t worth much at the turn of the 20th century. But when oil deposits were discovered
column3: everything changed.

column1: Grann says that in 1923
column2: with roughly 2
column3: 000 people on the tribal rolls
column4: the group “collectively got more than $30 million (in payments from oil companies leasing their land)
column5: ” which translates to about $500 million in today's dollars. And while “few Americans owned a car at that time
column6: many Osage had numerous cars
column7: as well as many servants
column8: often white.”

column1: ‘Maybe we’re all capable of this’:Martin Scorsese on ‘Killers of the Flower Moon’ movie
Grann says at least 24 Osage tribal members were murdered in order to get their oil rights
column2: so-called “headrights.” A typical way to get these rights was marrying into an Osage family. But as the book and movie explain
column3: sometimes there were shootings or slow poisonings to make the deaths look like mysterious ailments.

column1: While the “Killers” movie focuses on the evil schemes of one man
column2: William Hale (DeNiro)
column3: and his hapless nephew Ernest Burkhart (DiCaprio)
column4: “the real murders were less about a singular plot or evil figure with henchmen
column5: but rather many killings that were never properly investigated. Many people were complicit: Doctors with their poison
column6: morticians covering up causes of death
column7: lawmen staying silent. Many conclude the real death toll was in the scores
column8: if not hundreds.”

column1: Not likely
column2: says Grann. “There is no evidence that I know of that Mollie spoke to the president about the murders
column3: ” he says. “But it needs to be underscored that the Osage did go to Washington
column4: D.C.
column5: and she might have been on a trip.”

column1: Grann says Burkhart
column2: as the movie shows
column3: was so distraught by the deaths of her sisters that she “vigorously campaigned for justice
column4: offering testimony when needed and hiring private detectives to help find the killers.”

column2: a young J. Edgar Hoover
column3: who would wind up as the notorious and longstanding director of the FBI
column4: took over a new office then simply called the Bureau of Investigation. Hoover was eager to put his new group on the political map
column5: so he eagerly dispatched a former Texas Ranger
column6: Tom White (Jesse Plemons) to Oklahoma to investigate the mysterious Osage murders after local law enforcement hadn't solved the case.

column1: “This was among the first big complex homicide investigations by the fledgling Bureau of Investigation
column2: which would become the FBI
column3: ” says Grann. “At the time
column4: this office had limited jurisdiction over crimes nationally
column5: but it did have jurisdiction over crimes on federal (Native American) lands.”

column1: Grann adds that thanks in part to this case
column2: laws were passed in the 1930s that gave the FBI greater reach.

column1: “There was something unquestionably evil about Hale
column2: at his core
column3: ” says Grann. “According to the records he did show no remorse. He had created and was reflective of a pathological ideology of western expansionism
column4: a boosterism and a conviction' that the Native American way of life was ending. world was going.”

column1: Hale served his time and died at 87 in Arizona in 1962.
Our critic says:In 'Killers of the Flower Moon
column2: ' Martin Scorsese crafts a gripping story of love
column3: murder

column1: At the end of Scorsese’s “Killers
column2: ” the director makes a cameo appearance as an actor in a Lucky Strike cigarette-sponsored radio play about the Osage murders
column3: years after the case was closed..

column1: Grann says the story was the subject of a radio play
column2: but its purpose was less about sharing outrage of the treatment of Native Americans as glorifying the FBI's work.

column1: “Hoover wanted it to burnish his and the Bureau’s reputation
column2: so he organized these propagandistic retellings of what happened
column3: ” says Grann. “The scene in the movie is getting at the issue of how history is recorded
column4: and often misrecorded. Sure
column5: Hoover closed the case
column6: but there was a deep conspiracy surrounding the murders that the Bureau never exposed.”

column1: Ohio State's defense blanketed Penn State to deliver a 20-12 win in one of the most important games of the regular season.
Five years after James Franklin promised the Nittany Lions would eventually graduate to join the top teams in the Bowl Subdivision
column2: the loss reinforces the program's place: Penn State is very good
column3: but not elite. The Nittany Lions are treading water.

column1: And Ohio State is finding new ways to win games in the Big Ten. Clearly influenced by back-to-back losses to Michigan
column2: the Buckeyes are a physical team defined more so by defensive excellence than by an offense that has top-end skill talent but has taken a noticeable step back from the past two seasons.

column1: Penn State failed to convert a single third-down attempt until there was under a minute left. The Nittany Lions averaged just 2.6 yards per attempt on 25 carries. Drew Allar hit on just 18 of 43 throws for 191 yards
column2: an average of 4.3 yards per pass. A significant portion of his yardage and lone touchdown came on his team's final drive after Ohio State held a 14-point lead.

column1: The Buckeyes' failed fourth-down attempt on the goal line and a turnover on special teams gave Penn State chances to draw even in the second half. When in similar situations in the recent past
column2: Ohio State has pulled away from the Nittany Lions with pure offensive firepower. But the seventh win in a row in this series was sparked by a defense that may be one of the most improved units in the FBS. After Saturday
column3: the Buckeyes are giving up just 3.9 yards per play.

column1: This level of stinginess has been enough to offset a hit-or-miss offense that thrives when delivering the ball to All-America wide receiver Marvin Harrison Jr.
column2: who had 11 receptions for 162 yards and a touchdown. Going up against the Nittany Lions' own stout defense
column3: the Buckeyes managed to run for 79 yards while Kyle McCord went 23 of 35 for 286 yards.

column1: The win sets up a breezy four-game run before meeting the Wolverines to end November. Next
column2: Ohio State goes to Wisconsin and Rutgers before returning home for Michigan State and Minnesota. This monthlong stretch will give Ryan Day and the Buckeyes' offense more time to develop before heading into the winner-take-all rivalry game in Ann Arbor.

column1: The immediate future is hazier for Penn State. This was an incredible opportunity to end a long losing streak against an Ohio State that has clear flaws relative to the program's recent standard. With the loss
column2: the Nittany Lions are once again no better than a New Year's Six participant with Michigan still to come in November. The disappointment is palpable.

column1: The Buckeyes and Nittany Lions top Saturday's biggest winners and losers:
Basically buried after losing to Texas and struggling to put away South Florida in September
column2: Alabama has put together a series of close victories culminating in a 34-20 win against Tennessee to climb right back into the College Football Playoff race. Like earlier wins against Mississippi
column3: Arkansas and others
column4: beating Tennessee required a toned-down offense built around quarterback Jalen Milroe
column5: who completed 14 of 21 attempts for 220 yards and two scores with an interception. Down 20-7 at halftime
column6: the Crimson Tide outscored the Volunteers 27-0 in the second half to avenge last year's shootout loss. There are fewer style points than in the past but the results in league play have been familiar: Alabama is weighing teams down with a strong defense and doing a better job protecting the football while finding explosive plays downfield. And while the flash is missing
column7: the Crimson Tide have shown extreme mental toughness in weathering the early-season swoon to look like Georgia's biggest threat in the SEC.

column1: Florida State got 330 yards of total offense from quarterback Jordan Travis and remained unbeaten with a closer-than-it-looks 38-20 win against Duke. Riley Leonard was back in the the lineup for the Blue Devils
column2: but he struggled to get things going through the air even before leaving the game in the third quarter after apparently reinjuring the ankle he hurt in last month's close loss to Notre Dame. But the game turned at the moment Leonard left: FSU trailed 21-17 when Leonard went down but was in total control from that point forward. While Duke continues to impress even in defeat
column3: the Seminoles managed to pull out another resourceful win against one of the top teams in the ACC and remain on track for a conference championship game appearance and potential playoff berth.

column1: Missouri is good. Not win-the-SEC good
column2: obviously
column3: but this is a very improved team that is playing the best football to date under coach Eli Drinkwitz. The Tigers are now 7-1 after dispatching South Carolina
column4: taking a 24-3 lead at halftime and then sleepwalking through the second half to win 34-12. Missouri's defense did a nice job with Spencer Rattler
column5: limiting him to just 5.4 yards per attempt
column6: while the offense drew 159 yards and two touchdowns from running back Cody Schrader and a team-leading 90 receiving yards from potential All-America pick Luther Burden. Up next are Georgia
column7: Tennessee and Florida
column8: as Missouri prepares for meaningful November football for the first time in several years.

column1: Matt Rhule has Nebraska pointed toward bowl play after another strong performance from a rejuvenated defense sparked a 17-9 win against Northwestern. Now 4-3
column2: the Cornhuskers will have chances to get to six wins against a very friendly home stretch of games — Purdue
column3: Michigan State
column4: Maryland
column5: Wisconsin and Iowa — and could conceivably make the Big Ten title game. While deeply flawed team from an offensive perspective — the whole offense is taped together with sticks and branches
column6: making every positive gain an absolute adventure — that Nebraska could end the longest bowl drought in the Power Five in Rhule's first season would be an achievement that breathes enormous life into the program heading into 2024.

column1: Kansas State was all over TCU from the opening whistle of a 41-3 win that's probably the Wildcats' most complete performance of the season. While two tough setbacks against Missouri and Oklahoma State have knocked them out of the Top 25
column2: the Wildcats have moments when they look like one of two or three best teams in the Big 12 — Saturday being one of them. Kansas State continues to use a very interesting two-quarterback rotation of upperclassman Will Howard and true freshman Avery Johnson
column3: with the pair combining for 244 yards and four touchdowns without an interception with another 135 yards on the ground. Coach Chris Kleiman may have steered his team throughout a rough patch and pointed the Wildcats back toward the conference championship game.

column1: Saturday's loss drops Franklin to 1-9 against Ohio State and 4-15 combined against the Buckeyes and Michigan
column2: the Nittany Lions' opponent on Nov. 11. For all of the program's wins
column3: major-bowl appearances and overall success
column4: there is a sense of missed chances and unrealized expectations that grows even stronger with every successive failure against the best of the best in the Big Ten. The Nittany Lions could end up with double-digit wins but losing to the Buckeyes and Wolverines would only be a reminder of how far the program still has to go before truly competing for national championships.

column1: Another week
column2: another awful loss. And unlike last week's blowout defeat at Notre Dame
column3: this one came at home and featured more traditional heartbreak: Utah drove 54 yards in the final 1:46 and made a 38-yard field goal as time expired to beat Southern California 34-32. Quarterback Bryson Barnes had 235 passing yards
column4: four total touchdowns and a crucial scramble on the final drive to offset Caleb Williams' 256 passing yards and one rushing score. While this was a better performance overall than against the Fighting Irish and one that saw more moments of effectiveness from the USC defense
column5: these two losses in a row have caused the floor to give way for the Trojans
column6: and this year could get even worse with games ahead against Oregon
column7: Washington and UCLA.

column1: There was always this sense that unbeaten North Carolina was living on borrowed time. And then Drake Maye would throw for 350 yards and three scores to lift the Tar Heels to another high-scoring win. Luck finally ran out against an unexpected opponent
column2: Virginia
column3: which captured the biggest win of coach Tony Elliott's tenure by controlling the ball and keeping Maye on the sidelines in a a 31-27 upset. The Cavaliers had possession for more than 37 minutes and ran the ball 54 times for 228 yards
column4: offsetting the production of a UNC offense that still had 26 first downs and nearly 500 yards despite the limited touches.

column1: Clemson continues to drift toward its worst season since 2010 after a 28-20 overtime loss to Miami. The Tigers turned the ball over three times
column2: had a nonexistent running game and were still in position to win this game late into the fourth quarter
column3: only to allow the game-tying field goal with under two minutes left and fail to punch it in from inches away from the end zone in the second overtime. The win basically saves Miami’s season at a possible breaking point after losses to Georgia Tech and North Carolina
column4: and should temporarily quiet the increased scrutiny around coach Mario Cristobal. The loss is a devastating one for Clemson
column5: essentially ending any hope of regaining the ACC crown and officially signaling a second year in a row out of the playoff.

column1: This is the worst team in the SEC West and the worst offense in the SEC
column2: and that's combined to leave Sam Pittman on some shaky ground heading into the final four games of the regular season. You can write off any legitimate shot at the postseason after a 7-3 loss to Mississippi State
column3: the Razorbacks' sixth loss in a row and worst of the bunch. An way-too-empty stadium reflects the current state of affairs: Arkansas has gone from trendy to a total bore under Pittman.

column1: It was fun and games when Iowa was winning. But the jokes and eyerolls at the state of Iowa's offense will become a more serious concern after a 12-10 loss to Minnesota that saw the Hawkeyes deliver just 127 yards and fail to win despite keeping the Golden Gophers out of the end zone. Even worse
column2: the potential game-winning touchdown on a punt return from Cooper DeJean with under two minutes left was taken off the board after officials ruled DeJean had a made a fair-catch signal. One week after the Hawkeyes had seemed to put a headlock on the Big Ten West with a win against Wisconsin
column3: the division is back up for grabs.

column1: Wake Forest faced Pittsburgh without its starting quarterback and his backup
column2: leaving Dave Clawson to the turn the offense over to redshirt sophomore Santino Marucci
column3: whose career experience before Saturday consisted of six garbage-time snaps against Norfolk State two years ago
column4: all on special teams. You know exactly where this going. The Panthers were up 17-14 with 1:30 left after a 75-yard touchdown drive and then intercepted Marucci with just over a minute left. Even after punting back to Wake Forest only 23 seconds later
column5: Pittsburgh needed just one last defensive stop to secure a second win in a row. But Marucci marched the Demon Deacons 48 yards in 33 seconds
column6: connecting with Cameron Hite on a 15-yard score with seven seconds left
column7: to hand out the Panthers' worst loss in what has been a brutal season.

column1: FORT DODGE
column2: Iowa — Allison Roderick has a warning and a pledge for rural residents of her county: The water from their wells could be contaminated
column3: but the government can help make it safe.

column1: Roderick is the environmental health officer for Webster County in north-central Iowa
column2: where a few thousand rural residents live among sprawling corn and soybean fields. Many draw their water from private wells
column3: which are exempt from most federal testing and purity regulations. Roderick spreads the word that they aren’t exempt from danger.

column1: A former Connecticut postmaster could face 20 years in prison after pleading guilty to defrauding the U.S. Postal Service of $875
column2: 000 through bribery and embezzlement schemes.

column1: Ephrem D. Nguyen
column2: a postmaster for a postal office in Danbury
column3: Connecticut pleaded guilty on Oct. 13 to multiple schemes involving using USPS credit cards to pay a vendor about at least $760
column4: 000 more than necessary for maintenance and repair work
column5: according to a news release from the U.S. Attorney's Office.

column1: Additionally
column2: he said he embezzled over $80
column3: 000 with credit cards to rent vehicles for personal use and approved fraudulent travel expense reimbursement claims exceeding $8
column4: 000 for a co-worker.

column1: The former employee's work responsibilities included supervising maintenance and repair for USPS equipment
column2: facilities and vehicles.

column1: See also:Florida man found guilty of killing wife over her refusal to go on home renovation show
In late 2020
column2: Nguyen required that all maintenance and repair for the postal services go through a specific vendor despite knowing another vendor had been contracted for the office
column3: the news release states. He also demanded the vendor provide free vehicle maintenance and repairs for himself
column4: a co-worker
column5: one of his children and an employee of Nguyen's personal business.

column2: the former employee asked for and received $90
column3: 000 from the same vendor through cash bribes causing USPS to overpay the vendor for vehicle service that he called a "raise
column4:
according to the news release.
The accumulation of these defrauding schemes adds to about $874,930.59, the release states.
As federal employees
column5: we take an oath to protect the public
column6: including funds that have been allocated for federal services
column7: ” U.S. Attorney Avery said in the release. "This corrupt employee operated a brazen bribery
column8: kickback
column9: and embezzlement scheme that defrauded the U.S. Postal Service of hundreds of thousands of dollars.  I commend the USPS Office of Inspector General and the FBI for their excellent work in this investigation."

column1: The federal public defender representing Nguyen has declined requests for comment
column2: according to the Associated Press.

column1: The public must have confidence that Postal Service employees will conduct their work in an honest manner, Kenneth Cleevely
column2: a Special Agent for USPS' Inspector General

column1: Nguyen was released on a $100
column2: 00 bond and currently resides in Quincy
column3: Massachusetts where he awaits his sentencing.

column1: The hearing is scheduled for Jan. 5 and the honest service wire fraud he admitted to carries a maximum imprisonment term of 20 years

HOUSTON – If Adolis Garcia had simply winced
column2: tossed his bat aside and taken his base
column3: Bryan Abreu might still be eligible to pitch in the American League Championship Series.

column1: Instead
column2: Garcia
column3: the Texas Rangers slugger
column4: got in the face of Houston Astros catcher Martin Maldonado
column5: inciting a benches-clearing incident that resulted in Abreu’s ejection from Game 5 of the ALCS.

column1: Saturday
column2: Abreu learned he’d be suspended for the remainder of the series.

column1: Major League Baseball suspended Abreu for two games
column2: agreeing with the umpiring crew that Abreu threw intentionally at Garcia and taking “into account the dangerous nature of the pitch and its potential impact on player safety.”

column1: Abreu can appeal the suspension and is expected to do so. If the suspension is upheld
column2: Abreu would miss Sunday’s Game 6 and a potential Game 7 – or be out for Game 1 of the World Series. The Astros lead the ALCS 3-2 and can clinch the AL pennant at Minute Maid Park on Sunday.

column1: FOLLOW THE MONEY: MLB player salaries and payrolls for every major league team
Inactive players Lance McCullers and Matt Bush have also been barred from the dugout during games because they left the bench during the incident.

Abreu’s loss is significant for the Astros. He is perhaps their most dominant reliever and typically works the seventh or eighth inning setting up closer Ryan Pressly. Abreu struck out 100 batters in 72 innings and recorded a 1.75 ERA.
Friday’s Game 5 incident occurred after Garcia hit a go-ahead three-run homer off starter Justin Verlander and punctuated it with a bat spike and a deliberate walk down the first base line. Garcia
column2: Maldonado and Rangers second baseman Marcus Semien were also involved in a fracas during a July game.

column1: But the Astros were adamant that Abreu would not intentionally hit Garcia in a playoff game
column2: especially as they trailed 4-2 in the eighth inning of a pivotal game. An inning later
column3: Jose Altuve hit a three-run homer to give the Astros a 5-4 victory.

column1: “I’m the kind of guy
column2: I don’t care about celebrations. That was a big
column3: big moment for him. He got the chance to celebrate
column4: do whatever he wants
column5: ” Abreu said after Game 5. "I know that was a really hot moment. OK
column6: I get it. But obviously
column7: you’ve got to give me a warning or something. We’re just trying to compete.

column1: “I didn’t do anything wrong. It meant a lot to me.”
And Garcia obviously inflamed the situation
column2: earning an ejection himself after he jawed at Maldonado and forced home plate umpire Marvin Hudson to wedge himself between them.

column1: Astros manager Dusty Baker
column2: who was also ejected from Game 5 after angrily reacting to Abreu’s dismissal
column3: says he expects tensions may remain high in Sunday’s Game 6. How that manifests
column4: he does not know.

column1: “The players don't want to get into fights and skirmishes. And most of these guys know each other
column2: ” Baker said Saturday at Minute Maid Park. “Especially Latin guys are closer than anybody. But when emotions get high – have you ever gotten in an argument with your mom or your dad or your brothers?

column1: “It happens. And you don't script it. It's a spontaneous
column2: combustible reaction that gets out of control.”

column1: This is the second time this year that Neena Nizar’s wheelchair was damaged on a flight
column2: and she said it’s much worse now.

column1: “My wheelchair is totaled. I’ve had it break before but not like this
column2: ” she told USA TODAY.

column1: Nizar was flying home to Nebraska from Vancouver via Denver on United Airlines on Oct. 13
column2: and she said she watched her wheelchair fall off the baggage belt after landing in Omaha.

column1: “There was nobody holding it
column2: and there was nobody there to receive it so it fell right off
column3: ” she said. “That’s crazy
column4: it’s like
column5: are you kidding me?”

column1: In May
column2: the chair’s armrests were damaged after a flight on Southwest Airlines
column3: but the device was still usable. Now
column4: Nizar said
column5: her wheelchair won’t even turn on.

column1: Nizar realized the extent of the damage on the jet bridge and ultimately spent hours in the Omaha airport after her flight trying to see what recourse was available before eventually being pushed in her non-functioning wheelchair to the airport entrance and carried and driven home by her husband.
“I just started crying
column2: I was so upset
column3: I said
column4: ‘how could you do this?’ ” she said. “I was numb
column5: I was just in shock.”

column1: United Airlines acknowledged the incident in a statement to USA TODAY.

“We’ve been working with Ms. Nizar to get her a high-end loaner chair and her preferred vendor is currently assessing her wheelchair. We’ve apologized to Ms. Nizar and will cover the cost of repairs or a replacement
column2: depending on the final assessment
column3: ” the statement said.

column1: But Nizar said simply replacing her chair isn’t nearly sufficient compensation.

“I can’t walk my dog. I can’t go to the grocery. It was my son’s birthday the other day and I needed to go to the store multiple times and I couldn’t … I teach and I need to be able to go out and teach as well and I can’t do that
column2: ” she said. “I have to rearrange everything and they're not going to compensate for any of this.”

column1: For now
column2: Nizar said
column3: she’s stuck at home until she gets her chair replaced or a fully-functional loaner.

column1: “I asked them how am I going to get to work
column2: how am I going to continue to be able to put food on the table for my family if I can’t get around?” she said. “The response from one of the customer service people was ‘have someone drive you’ and it’s like
column3: ‘what? This isn’t my car that broke down
column4: this is my wheelchair
column5: this is like my legs.’ They just don’t understand.”

column1: Nizar said it could take up to a year for her chair to be fully replaced
column2: because the device needs to be custom fit to her body. She said the whole situation makes her feel unwanted by the travel industry.

column1: “I just feel even more angry that we are isolating this whole section of society who otherwise would be productive and moving around and working … It’s almost like a fear mechanism you’ve created that prevents people from doing what they need to do
column2: ” she said. “It’s not an option for me to stop traveling and I don’t want to stop traveling because it’s my right to travel.”

column1: According to the Department of Transportation
column2: airlines "mishandle" on average about 1.5% of the mobility equipment they transport. In 2022
column3: that translated to 11
column4: 389 incidents reported by U.S. airlines
column5: up from 7

column1: This year
column2: USA TODAY wants to highlight what those figures mean for travelers with disabilities. We're looking to track these incidents throughout 2023 with the goal of bringing light to an all-too-common problem.

column2: please share your story with us using the form below:
