The footage from the ceremony quieted from routine clapping for the graduates crossing the stage at Xavier University of Louisiana in New Orleans as the university president and everyone else in the auditorium spotted Aiyana Jones arriving in a wheelchair.
The crowd at the historically Black Catholic university's Convocation Center rose to its feet for the 22-year-old graduating with a biology degree and a Spanish minor.
Editor's note: Part one of a five-part USA TODAY series revealing why America hasn't solved its long struggle with Type 2 diabetes.
For chef Robin Ray
column2: newly married with young stepchildren
column3: the turning point came when a stabbing chest pain sent her rushing to the emergency room.

column1: For Brian Castrucci
column2: the gravity hit when the ER doc who had treated him for a near-heart attack a few weeks earlier gave him a big bear hug. “I didn’t think you’d make it
column3: ” the doctor said.

column1: The crisis unspooled more slowly for James Haynes but started in 2019 when he stepped on a rusty nail and didn’t notice.
The moments were turning points for all three to get serious about addressing their diabetes.
Type 2 diabetes
column2: in which the body can’t properly regulate blood sugar
column3: has become so common it’s almost considered inconsequential. More than 1 in 10 Americans have the disease (though many don't know) and another nearly 4 in 10 are at risk for it. In total
column4: half of all adults and a quarter of teenagers have diabetes or pre-diabetes.

column1: Its financial costs are astronomical. The country spends more than $300 billion a year to address diabetes
column2: accounting for $1 out of every $4 spent on health care.

column1: And its personal tolls are even worse: heart attacks
column2: amputations
column3: blindness
column4: kidney disease
column5: double the risk of premature death. It also causes what’s known as “diabetes distress
column6: ” the daily burdens and emotional toll of living with and managing a chronic ailment that can lead to regular dips in energy
column7: foggy thinking and depression
column8: and a sense of isolation.

column1: The most frustrating aspect of Type 2 diabetes
column2: experts say
column3: is that it has long been largely preventable and controllable.

column1: “We have made tremendous gains in understanding diabetes
column2: ” said Dr. Donald Berwick
column3: a pediatrician and former administrator of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services. “The best diabetes care can make a very big difference. You can’t say we don’t know what to do.”

column1: And yet
column2: diagnosed rates of Type 2 diabetes have soared over the past 25 years
column3: and especially over the past dozen – particularly among working-age adults like Ray
column4: Castrucci and Haynes.

column1: Roughly 40% of people who died early in the coronavirus pandemic had Type 2 diabetes
column2: a rate four times higher than people without the disease. Even when elevated blood sugar levels are below the threshold for type 2 diabetes
column3: the risk for heart disease jumps 30% to 50% compared with people with normal blood sugar levels. (Type 1 diabetes
column4: which accounts for 5% to 10% of diabetes
column5: is caused by the immune system and is unrelated to diet or lifestyle.)

column1: America’s failure to address Type 2 diabetes highlights larger problems with our food and medical systems
column2: Berwick and other experts said.

column1: A soda costs less than a bottle of water
column2: a double cheeseburger and fries less than a carton of blueberries. Patients wait months for medical appointments only to see the back of a white coat for the short time they’re allotted. Treating disease costs society far more than preventing it but typically provides more profit for insurance companies
column3: hospitals and the pharmaceutical industry.

column1: The USA TODAY Health team spoke with scores of health care providers
column2: researchers
column3: community leaders and patients for this five-part series to understand why Type 2 diabetes continues to worsen in America despite known solutions.

column1: The answer isn't simple. It involves systemic problems facing everyone in society
column2: not just those with diabetes: a food system designed to sell products; a medical system in which cutting off a leg is less expensive than saving it; the high cost of healthy living and the fact that breaking habits takes a lot more than just personal willpower.

column1: This first story looks at what it takes for people to cope with or overcome the disease.
Then
column2: we explore one community in a David vs. Goliath battle against a food system that fails to prioritize people's health.

column1: More in series:Diabetes runs deep in rural Mississippi. Locals have taken to growing their own solutions.
We next travel to Colorado
column2: which has the lowest level of diabetes in the nation. Yet even in this state
column3: where hiking trails and gorgeous views abound
column4: economic and other disparities make it easier for some people to avoid diabetes than others.

column1: More in series:A diabetes disparity: Why Colorado's healthy lifestyle brand isn't shared by all
It's tough to manage a chronic illness in the face of high medical costs
column2: scattered care and caregiver frustration and burnout
column3: so we highlight that next.

column1: More in series:The steep cost of Type 2: When diabetes dragged her down
column2: she chose to fight

column1: Finally
column2: we explore solutions
column3: addressing why it will take a combination of education
column4: medication
column5: medical devices and improved food access to solve this national problem.

column1: More in series:Solutions exist to end the Type 2 diabetes dilemma but too few get the help they need
The system is fixable
column2: said Dr. Dariush Mozaffarian
column3: a cardiologist and professor at the Tufts University School of Medicine in Boston.

column1: But it will take "sensible action" from across many sectors
column2: including health care
column3: science
column4: nutrition
column5: business
column6: public health and politics to change the financial and other incentives that drive so many Americans toward sickness instead of health.

column1: If we do it all, we could fix a lot of this in 10 years, said Mozaffarian
column2: who serves on the President’s Council on Sports
column3: Fitness
column4: and Nutrition. "If we do it incrementally or don't do it at all
column5: we're all going to be toast in 50 years from diet-related illnesses and a depleted environment."

column1: There’s no question personal responsibility plays a role in fighting diabetes.
Haynes
column2: Ray and Castrucci radically changed their lifestyles and sought help after their come-to-Jesus experiences. They’ve reduced their dependence on daily medication and hope to have saved themselves the horrors of more amputations
column3: blindness and dialysis. They’ve extended their lives and improved the quality of that time.

column1: But like many medical problems
column2: the challenges of diabetes go well beyond individual responsibility and blame.

column1: “There are structural issues that we have to start paying attention to and addressing
column2: ” said Dr. Shivani Agarwal
column3: an endocrinologist who specializes in research and treating young adults with diabetes at Montefiore Medical Center and Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York. Agarwal recently led a series of studies in the journal The Lancet that looked at diabetes rates around the world.

column1: Poverty
column2: the studies showed
column3: was a major driver of diabetes
column4: along with racism and unequal access to healthy food and high-quality medical care.

column1: Personal stories illustrate how these structural issues play out in the lives of so many Americans.
Ray
column3: director of culinary operations at HOSCO/North Sarah Food Hub in St. Louis
column4: got weight-loss surgery and then put her culinary expertise to good use.

column1: Castrucci
column3: who runs a public health nonprofit outside Washington
column4: D.C.
column5: used his advantages provided by his work
column6: salary and insurance to “buy” himself better health.

column1: “I’m healthy because of privilege – not diet
column2: not exercise
column3: not determination
column4: ” he said.

column1: Haynes
column3: a former truck driver and maintenance technician in Gulfport
column4: Mississippi
column5: has fewer material assets
column6: but his attitude and the advantages he does have explain why he's still around
column7: despite all he has been through.

column1: “It’s going to be all right after a while
column2: as long as I keep this spirit
column3: ” he said.

column1: Ray’s love for food began when she was 8 years old
column2: watching Julia Child on TV. During family gatherings
column3: she would run around taking everyone’s dinner order. Then she’d scurry back to the kitchen with a notepad full of scribbles.

column1: Throughout her life
column2: she made fried chicken
column3: pork chops
column4: baked mac and cheese
column5: collard greens
column6: and even a whole roasted chicken filled with wild rice and two sticks of butter – everything that made her soul sing.

column1: In her world
column2: food was home. Food was family. Food was love.

column1: But that was some pretty tough love.

column2: Ray was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes. Her father
column3: grandmother
column4: aunts and uncles all had diabetes. She knew what it meant.

column1: “For you to tell me I can’t have ice blue raspberry Kool-Aid was like you shut down my world
column2: ” Ray said. “I didn’t want to accept it. So
column3: I ate
column4: because you eat through your emotions.”

column1: She didn't dwell on the diagnosis and continued with life. Her culinary career took her to Italy
column2: where she learned and fell even more in love with food. She returned to St. Louis
column3: got married and became a mom to her husband’s two children ‒ “beautiful bonus babies
column4: ” as she described them. Through the years
column5: she continued to express love through cooking and eating.

column2: a stabbing chest pain sent her to the emergency room. Doctors assured Ray she hadn’t had a heart attack
column3: but they warned that her life was on the line. At 5-foot-2
column4: she weighed 334 pounds and had an A1C
column5: a measure of average blood sugar of 11%
column6: well above the 6.5% cutoff to be considered diabetic. Her diabetes – and her diet – were out of control.

column1: “That scared me. … It was gut-wrenching and terrifying
column2: ” she said. “I’m fighting against something that’s fighting me back and I did not know how to win.”

column1: She and her primary care doctor decided she would pursue weight loss surgery.
But she also decided to use her culinary prowess to transform her diet. She reconfigured favorite foods
column2: substituting healthier ingredients: Collard greens cooked in smoked fats or ham hocks turned into a kale
column3: turnip and rutabaga recipe flavored with natural chicken broth fat
column4: oils and seasonings.

column1: She fostered her feelings into new recipes and brought them to North Sarah Food Hub
column2: which partnered with Barnes-Jewish Hospital to make packaged
column3: pre-made meals for St. Louis residents with diabetes and limited access to fresh food.

column1: “I had to restructure the food that I put in my mouth. I had to think about what I was eating and how I was eating and how it was going to be good for my body
column2: ” she said. “I became excited about food again
column3: and food became a joy.”

column1: It isn’t always easy
column2: of course. Ray admits to an occasional cookie craving. But now she takes the time to think about how her body processes that cookie and whether it’s worthwhile.

column1: She hopes her cooking can help other people make the same transformation she did. Her staff at North Sarah helps her create new recipes for others. She wants to provide nourishment that allows people to avoid illness and medicine.
“Nobody wants to take 55 pills
column2: nobody wants to feel like a patient
column3: but how do you fix that? It’s by our food
column4: ” she said. “That should be what we’re teaching our community and our culture and our children. … It’s not always about the macaroni noodle with a smile
column5: it’s about what’s good for your body.”

column1: Castrucci is a third-generation diabetes patient. The lifetime risk of developing Type 2 diabetes if a parent has it is 40%. If both parents have it
column2: the risk jumps to 70%.

column1: He knew he was at risk
column2: but he pushed his luck
column3: he said
column4: by eating poorly during the pandemic and falling out of his exercise routine. With the luxury of working from home
column5: walking to the kitchen and bathroom was often the extent of his daily activity.

column1: On Feb. 14
column2: 2022 – Valentine’s Day – he went to an urgent care clinic
column3: concerned his breathing trouble meant he had bronchitis. His blood pressure measured 210 over 110
column4: well above normal levels that top out at 120 over 80. A chest X-ray showed fluid filling his lungs
column5: leading to congestive heart failure.

column1: The clinic sent him straight to a local emergency room
column2: where he was diagnosed with a blockage of the left descending artery – a clogged artery made worse by diabetes. If he had waited any longer
column3: he would have had a massive heart attack
column4: his doctor later told him.

column1: After his release from the hospital
column2: he went to the drugstore to fill his new prescriptions. The pharmacist told him she couldn’t fill one because it would cost $1
column3: 000. He’d have to wait until his insurance approved it. “Please fill it
column4: ” he said. She stressed the cost. “Fill it
column5: ” he pleaded
column6: putting the charge on his credit card.

column1: Medication helped him lose 70 pounds in three months. When his local drugstore ran out of the weight-loss drug
column2: he easily drove to another pharmacy and then another to find what he needed.

column1: His 100 hours of high-quality cardiac rehabilitation were fully covered by insurance.
For my midlife crisis, I got healthy, Castrucci said.
He could devote all his energy to getting well because he didn’t have to focus on how to afford his care. “(I) paid almost nothing for the whole episode
column2: ” he said
column3: “and never worried about it because I have really good insurance.”

column1: Even so
column2: Castrucci pays out-of-pocket for a cardiologist and an endocrinologist because the best ones near him don’t accept insurance.

column1: Every time he goes to Walgreens to refill his medications
column2: Castrucci said
column3: he sees someone turned away because they can’t afford their prescriptions. When they finally show up in the emergency room
column4: “because they will
column5: ” they will cost the system far more
column6: he said.

column1: “Health outcomes are dictated by economics. It’s a whole side of privilege that we don’t always talk about.”
On the day Haynes stepped on a rusty nail in 2019
column2: he walked all day as the nail pierced the sole of his sneaker and then his foot. By the time he took off his shoe that night
column3: his foot was infected. He landed in the hospital for two months as doctors and nurses tried
column4: mostly unsuccessfully
column5: to get the infection and Haynes’ blood sugar under control.

column1: By the time he was released
column2: he knew enough about Type 2 diabetes to realize his daily blood sugar levels – typically in the mid-400s – were four times above what he had been told to shoot for.

column1: But nothing he did or ate seemed to make a difference. He had long since traded ribs for salads
column2: beer for water.

column1: His wife
column2: Angela
column3: barely noticed when James started wearing multiple pairs of socks
column4: pouring powder on his feet and buying bigger shoes. His feet tingled a lot
column5: he said
column6: but he was coping with it.

column1: James ended up in the emergency room again
column2: dehydrated and in need of antibiotics. The doctor amputated the baby toe on his right foot
column3: leaving a large open wound.

column1:
We're going to leave this open because we'll probably have to take more,” Angela remembered the doctor saying. “I didn't like that we're not going to try to save anything, we're just going to start cutting.”
James was fading.
His arm muscles shriveled and he lost his Popeye physique. Antibiotics left him looking sickly, his voice so weak Angela could barely hear him. “I felt like I was watching my husband slowly dying,” she said.
Finally, taking her doctor sister’s advice, Angela emailed Dr. Foluso Fakorede’s office to ask for an appointment. She thought it would take months to get James in to see the heart disease specialist, but the office called and asked if they could come the next day. 
The Hayneses would end up going back to see Fakorede many times − sometimes twice in one week, driving more than five hours each way from Gulfport north to Cleveland, Mississippi.
“We started looking forward to these visits because there was always hope,” Angela Haynes said, though she felt guilty they were taking up so much of the important doctor’s time. 
Fakorede, who is on a personal mission to save people with diabetes from amputations, noticed what other doctors had missed. Haynes had blockages in blood vessels on both legs. 
Once he got the blood flowing again, Haynes began to feel better. His flesh returned to its normal color. The wound started healing at last. Walking became easier.
Then disaster struck again. 
On July 2, 2022, Haynes caught COVID-19. Everything went downhill after that
column2:
he said.
During his 13-day illness, the bacteria in his foot raged out of control. He ended up back in the hospital and unable to withstand the long drive to Fakorede’s office.
Every week, a surgeon would come to the door of his hospital room and before even stepping all the way in ask Haynes whether he had decided to get his leg amputated. 
This is my leg. I was born with this. And you're walking in like you're cutting a piece of cake
column3:
Haynes said.
He was worried about how he’d get around, how he’d be able to work to support his family if he had only one leg. No one took the time to explain why they thought the leg needed to come off or how he’d cope without it, Haynes said. 
In late November, he was finally sent home in a wheelchair. But just three weeks later, as he was getting out of the car after wound care, his right leg gave out and he fell to the ground. Back at the hospital, Haynes was told his foot was broken, essentially beyond repair. He agreed to a below-the-knee amputation.
Released right before Christmas, he spent the next three weeks in bed wondering how he’d manage the rest of his life.
Finally, it looked as if his luck might be turning around.
With the leg gone, his diabetes improved. His blood sugar dropped into the 120s or one-teens. His blurry vision cleared up.
During his long hospital stay, he befriended nurses and learned about a program for people who needed prostheses. The man who ran it called early in the year and said he had received a donated leg. If it fit Haynes, he could have it while waiting for insurance to pay for a personalized one. Miraculously, it did. 
Haynes spent the next six months teaching himself to walk again. The donor leg was heavy and uncomfortable. He wasn't mobile enough to hold down a job.
One late spring night, picking up dinner at a nearby restaurant, he headed to the bathroom for a pit stop. A sink had been leaking all day and Haynes slipped in the puddle, falling backward.
He's still recovering from the resulting wrist surgery.
He and Angela are living – barely – off her part-time salary as a secretary and a church organist.
Haynes has tried at least three or four times" to receive government assistance
column4: but they keep losing his paperwork
column5: or not believing he's disabled
column6: though he once checked himself out of the hospital and arrived at an appointment in his wheelchair to prove he didn't have a leg.

column1: Still
column2: he clings to his faith and the positive attitude he has long used to cheer up himself and others. These are his secret weapons against diabetes and everything else life throws his way.

column1: I try to put a smile on other people's faces, he said. "It keeps my day going."

Hamas – an acronym for Harakat al-Muqawama al-Islamiya, or the Islamic resistance movement – was founded in 1987 by activists connected to the Muslim Brotherhood during the first Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation of Gaza and the West Bank. The State Department designated Hamas a terrorist group in 1997, and several other nations also consider Hamas a terrorist organization.
In 2006, Hamas won parliamentary elections, and in 2007 the group violently seized control of Gaza from the Palestinian Authority, which was controlled by the rival Fatah movement that still governs the West Bank. There have been no elections since. The group calls for the establishment of an Islamic Palestinian state that would replace the current state of Israel and believes in the use of violence to carry out the destruction of Israel.
Hamas receives financial, material, and logistical support from Iran. So far, however, the U.S. and other nations have said there is no evidence that Iran was directly involved in Hamas’ attack.
Contributing: The Associated Press
The blood libel isn’t new – but it is terrifying to see it spread across the world in the wake of the Hamas massacre, its reach expanded and its impact intensified by shoddy news coverage of this crisis.
Palestinian terror groups’ false accusation that Israeli forces destroyed a hospital in Gaza was instantly covered as fact by journalists. As the unconfirmed allegation was highlighted in headlines, news feeds and push notifications, the reaction was immediate, threatening Jewish communities around the world.
This happened even as the allegation was quickly rebutted by the Israeli government. And U.S. sources have said that the missile likely was fired from within Gaza by Palestinian Islamic Jihad, a local terror organization that essentially serves as a junior version of Hamas.
As the sun rose, it became clear that, while the misfired missile had claimed casualties, the hospital had not been flattened. Indeed, independent experts assessed that it had been set ablaze by an explosion on the ground.
Based on overhead imagery, communications intercept and open-source data, governmental and nongovernmental sources confirmed that the damage likely had been caused by a rocket fired by terrorists inside Gaza. But it was far, far too late.
Journalists' knee-jerk assumption that Israel bombed a hospital already had attained escape velocity, traveling around the world and inflaming hatred along the way.
It was expected for Arab media to report the lie. Outlets like Al Jazeera has dispensed with any pretense of objectivity.
But it was even more damning to see Western media, including the New York Times and the Wall Street Journal, jump on the Hamas-driven charge and spread it without the normal processes that ensure the integrity of their reporting.
“Israeli Strike Kills Hundreds in Hospital, Palestinians Say,” blared a headline in The Times (later changed to “Israelis and Palestinians Blame Each Other for Blast at Gaza Hospital That Killed Hundreds.”)
In addition, reputable newspapers such as The Washington Post and news organizations such as The Associated Press and Reuters amplified the accusatory claims.
The level of incompetence was staggering – and dangerous.
In the 24 hours after the incident, the misinformation fueled a wave of antisemitic hate. There are almost too many examples to count. A synagogue in Germany was firebombed. Anti-Israel protesters descended on the U.S. Capitol and flooded Amman, Jordan; Beirut, Lebanon; and other capitals. This is just the beginning. 
Some, but not all, news outlets have backtracked on the claim and corrected the record. Fortunately, no one has been killed as a direct result of this irresponsible coverage. But the odds seem likely that people might be killed if this kind of misreporting reoccurs.
'Take a lesson from the dead':Fatal stabbing of 6-year-old serves warning to divided US as Israel-Hamas war rages
How does this happen?
When Hamas makes a claim, media outlets must ask hard questions. As a terrorist organization that forbids free speech and outlaws open expression, it has a track record of spreading lies and propaganda. Its leaders actively engage in information warfare, using all the means at their disposal.
For example, rather than cite the Ministry of Health in Gaza as a source, it would be more accurate to reference it as the Hamas Health Ministry, because it is an arm of the terrorist government. Outlets also should stop referring to Hamas operatives as “fighters” or “militants.” They are unrepentant terrorists whose malevolence is confirmed by more than 1,400 body bags in Israel, let alone the over 200 hostages, ranging from infants to the elderly, held against their will in the Gaza Strip.
Hamas invaded my brother's home.Now, my family is held hostage in Gaza.
But the problem is not just the official Hamas line. Western news agencies cannot operate bureaus in Gaza as they do in Israel and other democracies around the world. Reporters are not allowed to roam around and pursue stories at will. Instead, Hamas restricts who can report on the situation – and who cannot.
It is time for journalists to acknowledge their accountability in this crisis. Irresponsible reporting can enable the spread of a modern-day blood libel. The blood libel is an ancient charge, a pernicious myth that Jewish people intentionally kill non-Jews for any number of reasons.
An ancient form of fake news, the blood libel fueled antisemitic pogroms in Europe and was later imported to the Middle East.
Today, we see the blood libel in full effect when the world recklessly blames Israel for any number of crimes. It proliferates when, in this delicate moment, major media outlets fail to apply the normal checks and balances used to minimize misinformation. It has always been dangerous, but it is even more explosive in the Information Age because Jews around the world will be the victims.
As the Hamas war rages and tensions rise, media services around the world must take responsibility and prevent false information from spreading and fanning the flames of hate.
Jonathan A. Greenblatt is CEO and national director of ADL (the Anti-Defamation League).
As we can see in Ukraine and now the Middle East, wars of aggression, acts of genocide, tyranny and terrorist atrocities do not happen in isolation.
From the seeds of a strong-arm regime in Germany, sprouted with virulent antisemitism, came the continentwide extermination of Jews. The shadows of the Holocaust loom large, with contemporary Western society constructed upon the principle of never again." Yet

The latest guilty pleas from two key allies in Donald Trump's high-profile Georgia election interference case put new pressure on the former president and raise questions about whether his once-loyal associates may one day flip on him.
Two attorneys
column2: Kenneth Chesebro and Sidney Powell
column3: pleaded guilty to related crimes this week and agreed to testify against other defendants. They had been charged with playing separate roles in an alleged multi-pronged conspiracy to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election. Coming after a third defendant
column4: Scott Hall
column5: pleaded guilty in September
column6: their deals bolster the weapons in prosecutors' toolbox
column7: and may pressure other defendants to flip -- a move that would raise the legal stakes for Trump.

column1: ''Once you get a couple people pleading
column2: it starts sort of an avalanche of pleas
column3:
said Chandelle Summer, a Georgia attorney who previously worked as both a prosecutor and public defender in the state.
In addition to agreeing to testify, Chesebro, Powell, and Hall will turn over relevant documents to the state of Georgia, and are prohibited from communicating with witnesses or defendants in the case.
Norman Eisen, a Brookings Institution senior fellow who served as special counsel to the House Judiciary Committee from 2019 to 2020, said information from the three former Trump associates, could bolster the government's evidence in another pending Trump trial -- federal election meddling case, which is scheduled to start in March in Washington.
Both Powell and Chesebro were unindicted co-conspirators in the federal case
column4: so they're central to it
column5: Eisen said. It is ominous for the other defendants in the state or federal cases
column6: above all Donald Trump."

column1: Chesebro
column2: an election lawyer
column3: pleaded guilty Friday in the Fulton County Superior Court to a felony charge of conspiracy to commit filing false documents. Chesebro offers an inside view of the development of the scheme to recruit fake presidential electors to vote for Trump in states that President Joe Biden won.

column1: Chesebro created and distributed false documents in Georgia and other states for people to submit to the National Archives and Congress posing as presidential electors
column2: according to Daysha Young
column3: the executive district attorney in Fulton County.

column1: The defendant provided detailed instructions to co-conspirators in Georgia and other states for creating and distributing these false documents, she said.
Chesebro's deal gets the prosecution closer to John Eastman
column2: who around that time appears to have been in "constant communication" with Rudy Giuliani and Donald Trump
column3: said Melissa Redmon
column4: a former Fulton County prosecutor who directs the University of Georgia School of Law's Prosecutorial Justice Program.

column1: Those connections will help the state paint a picture for the jury of the false elector activity being ultimately motivated by a desire to make sure Trump retained the presidency "by any means necessary
column2:
Redmon said.
Sixteen co-defendants in the Georgia case, including Trump, Eastman and Giuliani, have pleaded not guilty.
Powell, an election lawyer who spread baseless claims of voter fraud, pleaded guilty Thursday to a half-dozen misdemeanors associated with tampering with election equipment in Coffee County, Georgia.
Legal experts said Powell's agreement to provide testimony could have a weighty impact on the wider case because she had significant dealings with Trump, Giuliani, and others.
Powell can also describe how co-defendants tried to overturn the 2020 election. She and Giuliani attended a raucous meeting at the White House with Trump, where they discussed having the military seize voting machines. Trump never acted on the proposal.
Hall, a bail bondsman who served as a go-between for several of the co-defendants, pleaded guilty in September to five misdemeanors dealing with interfering with election duties.
Hall helped SullivanStrickler employees tamper with the Coffee County equipment.
Hall also made multiple calls to co-defendants in the case. For example, Hall spoke with Jeffrey Clark, a former assistant attorney general, for more than an hour Jan. 2, 2021, according to the indictment.
Clark, who pleaded not guilty, is charged with drafting a letter of false statements about Justice Department concerns with the 2020 election, to be sent to Georgia officials. Acting Attorney General Jeffrey Rosen refused to sign or send the letter.
Hall also spoke repeatedly with co-defendants accused of trying to intimidate election workers to change their stories about what happened with ballot counting at State Farm Arena on election night 2020.
Although the pleas open up several months on McAfee's calendar that had been reserved for Powell and Chesebro's trial, Redmon said typically in Fulton County there are several steps involving pre-trial deadlines before a trial date is set in a case, and she doesn't expect to see a trial date for Trump soon.
Summer said McAfee would have to take the schedules for Trump's other criminal trials into account, as well as his attorneys' scheduling conflicts.
Assuming he's acquitted in the DC case
column3: I think then they'll probably specially set a trial for sometime after that
column4: maybe the fall of 2024
column5:
she said.
Eisen suggested McAfee might aim to hold Trump's Georgia trial sooner.
If Chesebro and Powell could get ready for trial on an accelerated basis
column6: surely it's not too unreasonable for Trump and possibly other defendants to prepare themselves to face a jury in Atlanta at some point in the coming months

Eisen said.
EXETER, N.H. — GOP presidential hopeful Vivek Ramaswamy is leaning on one major message in his pitch to New Hampshire’s first-in-the-nation primary voters: the need to revive a common U.S. national identity. 
“We don’t have to be a nation in decline,” Ramaswamy said at a Republican presidential town hall hosted by the USA TODAY Network, comparing the U.S. to a teenager. “We are just a little young, going through our own version of adolescence, figuring out who we’re really going to be when we grow up.”  
Ramaswamy, who officially filed Wednesday to appear on the Granite State’s Republican primary ballot, argued that half the job of the next U.S. president is to lead the the country out of its ongoing culture wars. The other half, he suggested, will be to steer the policy agenda in Washington.
So what is the 38-year-old political newcomers vision for America's future? During the Exeter, New Hampshire town hall, Ramaswamy laid out his policy priorities to reduce the federal deficit, support Israel and counter China. Here's how his pitch impacts Americans across the country.  
If elected, Ramaswamy told voters that he plans to shut down some major U.S. federal agencies, including the Department of Education.  
There are certain people
column8: good people
column9: in this race
column10: that will favor incremental reform of the federal government and the bureaucracy
column11: he said. I'm not in that camp. I favor quantum leap change. I don't believe it is possible to incrementally reform agencies that have existed for a long time."

column1: Echoing a common Republican talking point
column2: Ramaswamy argued that education decisions should be put in the hands of parents. He said he’d opt to send the department's $80 billion in funding back to taxpayers to “economically empower” them to choose a school for their children.

column1: “My view is we have a fourth branch of government that is unconstitutional
column2: ” Ramaswamy told voters. “The correct answer is shut it down and give the power and the money back to the people.”

column1: To reduce the $33 trillion in U.S. debt
column2: Ramaswamy floated a zero-based budgeting approach.

column1: When drafting the annual federal budget
column2: Ramaswamy said he’d “start with zero as the baseline and then ask what’s actually necessary
column3: ” rather than referring to the previous year’s budget as a jumping-off point.

column1: The same tactic was adopted by former President Jimmy Carter in the late 1970s but was not found to reduce costs and was later abandoned by former President Ronald Reagan.
With tensions rising in the war between Israel and Hamas
column2: Ramaswamy last week defended Israel’s right to protect its homeland but cautioned that
column3: as president
column4: he would put American interests at the center of his foreign policy agenda.

column1: “We have to provide Israel with diplomatic support
column2: munitions support as needed and further even provide them with intelligence sharing
column3: ” Ramaswamy told voters gathered at the Exeter town hall.

column1: Ramaswamy called for providing the support in a way that “avoids broader regional conflict in the Middle East.” The perspective is largely shaped by his views on prior U.S. involvement in Afghanistan and Iraq.
“The Taliban is still in charge in Afghanistan 20 years later and frankly (there is) a hostile anti-American regime in Iraq that's vulnerable to Iranian incursion
column2: ” Ramaswamy said. “That didn't advance American interests and we have to own up to that."

column1: On Ukraine’s war front with Russia
column2: Ramaswamy expressed support for a “reasonable path to peace
column3: ” but did not define his views on what that might entail. Previously
column4: the biotech entrepreneur has proposed allowing Russia to keep the Donbas region and requiring Ukraine to concede its attempts to join NATO.

column1: Describing Vladimir Putin as a “craven dictator
column2: ” Ramaswamy told voters in New Hampshire that “just because Russia is bad doesn’t mean Ukraine is good or perfect.”

column1: He called for reopening relations between the U.S. and Russia and said that such an alliance would help counter China.
“Do I trust Putin? No. But I do trust him to follow his self-interest
column2: ” Ramaswamy told voters. “China’s top bet right now is that the U.S. won’t want to go to war with two allied superpowers at the same time. But if Russia’s no longer in China’s camp then Xi Jinping is going to actually have to think twice.”

column1: Other Republican presidential candidates have fiercely criticized Ramaswamy’s foreign policy stances. During a confrontation at the first GOP debate
column2: for instance
column3: former South Carolina Gov. Nikki Haley admonished Ramaswamy for his inexperience.

column1: “You want to go and defund Israel
column2: you want to give Taiwan to China. You want to go and give Ukraine to Russia
column3: ” she said. “Under your watch
column4: you will make America less safe.”

column1: Imagine a young married couple. One partner invests heavily in his employer’s 401(k)
column2: saving for both spouses. The other focuses on paying the bills and contributes nothing to her retirement plan
column3: missing out on the employer's matching funds.

column1: That was how Niv Persaud and her husband handled their finances.
“My income was going toward our expenses
column2: and he was going to focus on retirement
column3: ” she said. “And I had a great company match
column4: and I didn’t pay attention to that.”

column1: The marriage eventually ended. Three decades later
column2: Persaud works as a certified financial planner in Atlanta. Her lost retirement savings provide a cautionary tale.

column1: How much potential savings did she lose?
Protect your assets: Best high-yield savings accounts of 2023
“I don’t even want to think about it
column2: ” she said.

column1: In fact
column2: one in four married couples fails to take full advantage of employers who make matching contributions to 401(k) retirement plans
column3: a recent study found. The oversight costs them nearly $700 a year
column4: on average.

column1: Nearly two-thirds of American workers have access to an employer-sponsored defined contribution retirement savings plan
column2: according to the paper
column3: titled “Efficiency in Household Decision Making: Evidence from the Retirement Savings of U.S. Couples
column4: ” and released in April by the National Bureau of Economic Research.

column1: Most plans offer a match: The employer contributes to a 401(k)
column2: matching some or all of the funds paid into the plan by the worker. In one typical model
column3: the employer matches half of every dollar a worker contributes
column4: up to a maximum of 6% of the worker’s pay.

column1: The study found that about 24% of married couples left money on the table by failing to claim some of an employer’s matching funds. Those couples lost $682 a year
column2: on average
column3: money they could recover simply by changing the allocation of their retirement contributions. The findings are based on IRS tax data and retirement plan descriptions.

column1: “There’s a lot of advice around
column2: ‘You should save more
column3: ’” said Taha Choukhmane
column4: an assistant professor of finance at the MIT Sloan School of Management. “It’s not just how much you save. It’s how you save
column5: and where you save.”

column1: Choukhmane co-authored the working paper with Cormac O’Dea
column2: an assistant professor of economics at Yale
column3: and Lucas Goodman
column4: an economist at the Treasury Department.

column1: The researchers stressed that their focus was not on couples that don’t save for retirement
column2: or don’t save enough. Instead
column3: they looked at couples that could increase their savings merely by shifting contributions from one spouse to the other.

column1: “You don’t need to save more. You don’t need to change how you spend
column2: ” Choukhmane said. “It’s all about how you allocate money across accounts.”

column1: In some couples
column2: the researchers found
column3: only one spouse contributed to a retirement plan
column4: while the other ignored a plan with a generous employer match. Other couples split retirement savings equally when they should have put more money into an account with a larger match.

column1: “The 401(k) is really designed around individuals
column2: ” Choukhmane said. “And I think a lot of people need to realize that this is not about the individual.”

column1: The new study underscores a lack of cooperation between spouses on an important matter of household finance. The researchers said it also speaks to the broader issue of financial communication in marriage.
“It does open up a question of what other big decisions couples are not coordinating on
column2: ” O’Dea
column3: the assistant professor at Yale
column4: said.

column1: The researchers found that couples that had been married longer
column2: and couples with children
column3: tended to do a better job at communicating and coordinating retirement savings. Couples in shorter relationships did worse.

column1: Couples headed for divorce were also less likely to coordinate their retirement contributions. The researchers discovered this by studying the saving patterns of marriages that ended in divorce.
Investment advisers often recommend that American workers save 10% to 15% of their pre-tax income for retirement. They also urge them to max out any matching funds from the employer
column2: which boosts the worker’s effective savings rate.

column1: If a company matches up to 6% of your salary in 401(k) contributions
column2: "maxing out" means contributing at least that much of your annual pay.

column1: “The first priority for any investor should be to save enough to get at least the entire employer match
column2: ” said Rob Williams
column3: managing director of financial planning at Charles Schwab.

column1: Yet

column1: As the holiday season approaches
column2: two major grocery chains have announced they are reducing prices to help customers deal with inflation.

column1: On Wednesday
column2: Walmart announced it will be "removing inflation
column3:
offering Thanksgiving meals at lower prices than in 2022, according a press release. The supermarket giant will offer two Thanksgiving meal options this year: one with ingredients for customers who like to cook from scratch, and one for customers who prefer more ready-to-bake options.
Walmart's Thanksgiving meal basket includes main dishes and sides options from national brands, including turkey for under $1 a pound, ham, stuffing and pumpkin pie. Theses baskets can be purchased through Walmart's website or app for pickup or delivery.
These holiday prices don't just apply to Thanksgiving: Walmart's deals begin Nov. 1 and are valid through Dec. 26, 2023.
Aldi has also turned its focus toward holiday prices, announcing Wednesday that it will reduce the price on over 70 items around the store by up to 50%.
The price reductions include seasonal items like gravy, potatoes, green beans, cranberries and pumpkin pie, according to a press release, but also includes kitchen staples like butter and flour.
Aldi's price reductions will begin Nov. 1 and last through the end of the year.
Food:Kraft Mac & Cheese ice cream is back at Walmart next week along with six new flavors by Van Leeuwen
USA TODAY has reported that annual inflation has fallen this year since hitting a 40-year high of 9.1% in June 2022.
Bu- tit was reported at 3.7% in September, well above the Federal Reserve's 2% target.
Consumer price increases stayed high in September, and there was a small rise in gasoline and food costs.

CVS is pulling over-the-counter allergy and cold medicines that contain the most popular decongestant ingredient from its shelves. The ingredient, phenylephrine, was found to be no more effective than a placebo when taken orally by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration last month.
We are removing a small number of oral decongestant products that contain phenylephrine as the only active ingredient from CVS Pharmacy stores but will continue offering many other oral cough and cold products to meet consumer needs
column4:
a spokesperson for CVS Health told USA TODAY in a statement.
Phenylephrine can be found in name brand decongestants such as Sudafed and Dayquil, and became the primary ingredient in most of these medications after a 2006 law limited access to pseudoephedrine, which can be used to make methamphetamine.
Products like Dayquil will remain on CVS shelves since they have a combination of active ingredients.
More:FDA panel declares decongestant phenylephrine ineffective. What it is and what products contain it
Since 2007, the efficacy of phenylephrine to provide nasal congestion relief has been challenged.
In September, the group of FDA-assembled advisors unanimously voted oral phenylephrine ineffective a thorough review of" data going back to 1994
column5: and that the drug metabolizes in the body before it reaches the nasal passages. The panel vote is not a medical determination.

column1: There were no safety issues found with taking oral phenylephrine.
The experts said some potential benefits of removing the ingredient include "lowering of overall healthcare costs
column2: and avoiding missed opportunities for use of more effective treatments" like going to the doctor.

column1: Medications with phenylephrine generated $1.8 billion in sales last year
column2: according to the FDA report.

column1: Not all pharmacy chains will remove products. In a statement to USA TODAY
column2: a Rite Aid spokesperson said the company will keep those over-the-counter medications on its shelves:

column1: Our pharmacists are available to provide guidance to customers on over-the-counter solutions for alleviating symptoms associated with colds and other illnesses.

column1: Many of us have been there before: waking in the middle of the night
column2: often in response to a dream or nightmare
column3: afraid and covered in perspiration.

column1: While sweating has many benefits
column2: such as being a "natural function that the body uses to regulate body temperature
column3:
explains Jewel Kling, MD, assistant director of women's health for Mayo Clinic, it can also be a source of concern. 
For instance, some people worry that their sweat causes body odor, while others fret that their obvious sweating is a sign they're nervous or anxious (which it may well be, but they don't want others to know that). But for people who sweat a lot at night, perspiration can be especially disruptive to a healthy sleep schedule, and even costly due to the amount of laundry it can create. 
Nights sweats are repeated episodes of very excessive sweating that occur during sleep - often heavy enough to soak through nightclothes or bedding, per Mayo Clinic. Such episodes can occur whether one's sleeping environment is hot or cold. 
Night sweats can range from moderate to excessive with drenching sweats
column4:
explains Kling. Like episodes of excessive sweating that can occur during the day, night sweats are usually considered generalized hyperhidrosis, or heavy sweating. Such perspiration can happen on its own or it may be accompanied by an illness such as fever or nausea. 
While various things can cause or contribute to night sweats including medication and medical conditions, it is recommended that when you frequently experience night sweat
column5: you have it evaluated by your clinician to identify the cause
column6:
suggests Kling. 
Another such cause many include hormonal changes like menopause, which can make it hard for the brain to regulate body temperature, often causing night sweat. Infection can contribute as well; as can night terrors or bad dreams. Stress
column7: increased heart rate
column8: and other stimuli can trigger night sweating
column9:
says Anthony Beutler, MD, an associate medical director of sports medicine at Intermountain Health in Salt Lake City.
Other culprits of night sweats include vitamin B12 deficiency, excess weight, dysfunction within the autonomic nervous system or certain disorders of the endocrine system such as thyroid disease. 
And each such factor can lead to different degrees of night sweating. The composition of sweat varies considerably
column10: depending on its cause
column11:
explains Loren Fishman, MD, a professor of physical medicine and rehabilitation at Columbia University.  
It's also worth noting that night sweat is not the same as exercise-related sweat in a couple distinct ways. The chemical composition of perspiration from night sweats
column12: like that from other emotional or endocrine causes
column13: is different in its chemical composition from exercise-induced perspiration
column14:
says Fishman. To explain this, he says that sweat from normal activity is higher in lactate - a product of metabolism - than the sweat produced while sleeping.
Kling adds that night sweat and exercise-related sweat also have different functions, even if the mechanisms that lead to perspiration are similar. Exercise-related sweating is triggered by the body during exercise to control body temperature
column15: she explains. Night sweats are typically caused by something else."

column1: More:Sweating cools us down
column2: but does it burn calories?

column1: When you're messaging someone
column2: you don't want to overload them with information. Sometimes
column3: sending a lengthy paragraph can feel like too much. You also may want to avoid the dreaded "double text
column4:
or in some cases, triple or quadruple text.
This is where slang and abbreviations come in to help. There is a whole library of examples at your fingertips – from ily" and "rizz" to "OP" and "fwiw."

column1: ICYMI
column2: USA TODAY has been breaking down text slang. Now
column3: it's time to learn a new one. Here is the meaning and how to use "fyi."

column1: FYI stands for "for your information." When used
column2: the term notifies others about something that is important or significant.

column1: The abbreviation can be used in both formal and informal messaging
column2: such as via email to relay a deadline at work or while texting a friend about some interesting gossip.

column1: The usage of "FYI" can be traced back to the 1930s when it was used by journalists to denote that the messages – or parts of the messages – they sent were for the recipient only
column2: not for public viewing
column3: according to Grammarly.

column1: While only 12.3% of U.S. adults meet the recommended fruit and vegetable intake
column2: the grains group isn’t one that Americans have trouble getting enough of
column3: MyPlate says. Grains show up in many parts of our day – cereals and bagels in the morning
column4: sandwiches at lunchtime
column5: rice at dinner or popcorn while watching a movie.

column1: But while the quantity may not be an issue
column2: the quality is: the U.S. Department of Agriculture recommends more of your grain intake be from whole grains than refined.

column1: Here are the healthiest options within that whole grain category.
Grains are an important source of fiber
column2: B vitamins
column3: complex carbohydrates and minerals like iron
column4: magnesium and selenium. The carbohydrates in grains are crucial because they’re “direct and easy sources of energy for your body” says registered dietitian Chris Mohr.

column1: While all whole grains will provide these nutrients
column2: there are a few that stand out. Farro
column3: oats and quinoa may be the healthiest grains because of their heavy fiber content.

column1: “Fiber’s not the sexiest nutrient to talk about because of the benefits
column2: but it’s critical for health
column3: ” Mohr says.

column1: Dietary fiber helps you feel fuller
column2: aids in digestion and helps prevent constipation. Research presented at the 2021 American Society for Nutrition conference found fewer than 1 in 10 U.S. adults meet their daily fiber recommendations. The Dietary Guidelines for Americans recommend eating 28 grams of fiber per day based on a 2
column3: 000-calorie diet.

column1: You’re also getting protein with these three options. A serving of oats (100 grams) contains nearly 17 grams of protein and 10.6 grams of fiber. A serving of farro of the same size contains 15.4 grams of protein and 6.6 grams of fiber. For cooked quinoa
column2: it’s about 3 grams of fiber and 4.4 grams of protein.

column1: For comparison’s sake
column2: the same portion of white rice contains about 2.7 grams of protein and 0.4 grams of fiber.

column1: But while these three are great options
column2: Mohr says you ideally want to eat a variety of grains to get different nutrients.

column1: The USDA recommends at least half your daily grain intake be whole grains
column2: which contain more vitamins and nutrients than refined grains. Mohr says we shouldn’t be scared of refined grains but should make sure they’re enriched.

column1: The refinement process gives grains a finer texture and longer shelf life – we see this in cereal
column2: white flour
column3: white bread and white rice
column4: for example. Today
column5: many refined grains are enriched
column6: which means they add back nutrients like B vitamins and iron but not fiber. Enriched
column7: refined grains do add folic acid
column8: however
column9: which Mohr says even whole grains don’t include as much of in their natural form.

column1: Folic acid is recommended during pregnancy because of its role in DNA and RNA formation
column2: but it’s important for everyone. The benefits of folate include improved digestive system functioning and preventing common cancers
column3: cardiovascular disease
column4: infertility
column5: stroke
column6: dementia and Alzheimer’s disease.

column1: “That’s why it’s important to make sure that you are getting even some refined grains because they are enriched specifically with folic acid
column2: ” Mohr says.

column1: Check the packaging or nutrition labels to tell if a refined grain is enriched. Organic products may not be fortified.
What is the healthiest bread?:One is best
column2: but you've got plenty of options

column1: To understand whole grains
column2: you first have to understand grain kernel anatomy. The kernel is made of three parts:

column1: Whole grains are just as they sound – the entire grain kernel remains intact. When you refine grains
column2: it strips the grain of the bran and germ and uses just the inside endosperm. This removes most of the grain's vitamins
column3: minerals
column4: fiber and protein.

column1: It’s important to know how to look for whole grains when you’re grocery shopping. You can’t use a darker color as a judge
column2: because breads and other grain products are sometimes dyed with molasses
column3: according to Mohr. You have to look at the ingredient list.

column1: “You want the words ‘whole grain’ to be at the beginning of the ingredient list
column2: ” he says.

column1: The easiest swap is to consciously add in more whole grain products to tip you over to that “more than half” whole grain recommendation. This could be trying whole grain bread instead of whole wheat or white bread
column2: having brown rice or wild rice every once in a while if you normally eat white rice or looking for whole grain bagel options
column3: Mohr says.

column1: Whole grain cereals can be another good addition to your mornings – routinely consuming ready-to-eat cereals
column2: especially whole grain ones
column3: is associated with significant increases in overall dietary fiber intake.

If you struggle with blemished or aging skin
column2: or from a skin condition such as acne
column3: chances are you've tried many natural remedies to help. These may have included apple cider vinegar
column4: vitamin supplements
column5: essential oils or even a viral honey and cinnamon mask you may have seen trending on social media.

column1: But chances are
column2: you've also turned to prescription and over-the-counter medications or topical applications in an attempt to find a solution. While there are many products offered by the $146-billion-dollar skin-care industry which include vitamin C serum and a host of lotions and creams
column3: few such products or ingredients are more sought after than retinol.

column1: Retinol is a form of the fat-soluble nutrient vitamin A
column2: and is a popular ingredient in skin cream topicals for its anti-aging effects. It's a type of retinoid - chemical compounds derived from vitamin A or chemically related to it - but is unique in that most retinoids are considered powerful enough to require a prescription while the retinol formula is mild enough to be available in over-the-counter form.

column1: Retinol is most commonly applied topically and only a small amount is needed, explains Dustin Portela
column2: DO
column3: a board-certified dermatologist and founder of Treasure Valley Dermatology in Boise
column4: Idaho. "To my patients
column5: I recommend using a pea-size amount of cream or gel
column6: or about four drops of the serum
column7: to cover the whole face."

column1: Though retinol is mainly used as a lotion
column2: cream
column3: gel or serum
column4: retinol-related medications can be taken orally as well to treat skin conditions and to help "prevent skin cancers in patients at higher risk of skin malignancies
column5:
says Anna Chien, MD, a board-certified dermatologist practicing in Columbia, Maryland, and an associate professor of dermatology at Johns Hopkins School of Medicine.
Retinol is effective in a number of ways. It can unclog pores (and thereby improve acne), neutralize free radicals and exfoliate one's skin. Retinol acts inside your skin cells on several different molecular pathways to help improve the skin's appearance
column6:
explains Portela. In this way, he says it can help boost collagen production and also minimize wrinkles and fine lines. 
Chien says that retinol can also improve skin turnover, decrease the size of sebaceous glands (glands found in hair follicles that secrete the oily substance sebum), even out pigmentation, decrease skin proliferation, improve skin texture and protect against signs of aging. Because of such varied functions, it's used topically for acne
column7: skin aging
column8: discoloration and for certain skin diseases such as psoriasis
column9:
she says. 
While many people reap such benefits without experiencing side effects, retinol does come with some risks
column10: says Portela. He says the most common one is irritation of the skin. It can disrupt the moisture barrier if you use too much or too strong of a retinol for your skin type
column11:
he cautions. 
Another area of concern is that it's possible for retinol to increase one's sensitivity to the sun. Because of this, it is especially important to wear a daily sunscreen if you have incorporated retinol into your skin care routine
column12:
Portela advises. Retinol is also not generally recommended for use while pregnant.
When it comes to decreasing retinol's side effects related to skin irritation, Chien says that can be managed with careful titration of its usage (combined with) a gentle skin care routine."

In the 24 hours after the incident

When Hamas makes a claim

column1: For example

column1: Ethics can be difficult.
Except when they’re not.
Except they will be.
Because this is Arizona.
For example
column2: soon to come before the Arizona Supreme Court is a case that could revive an 1864
column3: pre-statehood abortion ban that mandates as much as a five-year prison term for providers.

column1: Among the seven members of the court who will decide that case is Bill Montgomery
column2: a hyper-political
column3: hyper-partisan
column4: virulent anti-abortion former prosecutor appointed by former Gov. Doug Ducey.

column1: The Arizona Mirror and The 19th (a nonprofit
column2: independent news operation out of Austin
column3: Texas) noted in an article that Montgomery said in the past that Planned Parenthood (whose lawyers are arguing against reinstating the 1864 law) “is responsible for the greatest genocide known to man.”

column1: Now for the ethics part. And please
column2: try not to laugh out loud when you read the next sentence.

column1: Arizona has an official “Code of Judicial Conduct.”
(I can hear you.)
Anyway
column2: Rule 2.11 of that code
column3: under “Disqualification
column4: ” reads in part
column5: “A judge shall disqualify himself or herself in any proceeding in which the judge’s impartiality might reasonably be questioned … .”

column1: Montgomery didn’t only make the “genocide” comment. He was never shy about his feelings.
I never expected I'd need an abortion.Our outdated laws made me pay for it myself.
At a protest in front of Planned Parenthood’s offices a few years back
column2: he said
column3: “Today’s protest calls for several specific goals. We call for Congress to end federal funding for Planned Parenthood. There is no reason to fund this charade of women’s health care any longer. The profit-driven atrocities must end and America must not fund them anymore.”

column1: Seems pretty clear that Montgomery’s “impartiality might reasonably be questioned.” And that he should disqualify himself.
Except
column2: perhaps
column3: in Arizona.

column1: This isn’t new. Former Gov. Ducey first increased the number of judges on the Supreme Court from five to seven (when no one said it was needed)
column2: then stacked the court with partisans like Montgomery.

column1: Republicans controlled Arizona.Then Turning Point USA tried to help.
The first time Montgomery came up for consideration
column2: Chief Justice Scott Bales told Montgomery
column3: “One broad statement is that you have very strongly held beliefs that have been expressed in different settings
column4: which give people concerns about your ability as a judge to be fair.”

column1: When the former prosecutor didn’t make the cut that time around
column2: Ducey rigged the supposedly neutral system for selecting judicial candidates to pick the judges he wanted
column3: like Montgomery.

column1: When Montgomery was under consideration
column2: Scott O’Connor
column3: the son of former U.S. Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O’Connor
column4: said selecting someone like him for the state’s highest court “will do no service to the public’s faith in the judicial system.”

column1: What would bolster the public’s faith in the judicial system?
Ethics.
But ethics can be difficult.
Except when they’re not.
Except they will be.
Because this is Arizona.
EJ Montini is a columnist at The Arizona Republic/azcentral.com
column2: where this column first published. Reach Montini at ed.montini@arizonarepublic.com.

column1: Lawyers all over the state of Tennessee are scratching their heads about the Michael Oher conservatorship and the ensuing litigation.
On Aug. 9
column3: a lawyer in Hernando
column4: Mississippi
column5: filed a petition on behalf of Sean Tuohy and his wife
column6: Leigh Anne Tuohy
column7: to be appointed conservators over Michael Oher (the “Respondent”). The petition states that the court should grant the Tuohys “full co-legal custody
column8: guardianship and conservatorship” over Oher.

column1: Although the petition asks that the Tuohys be named conservators over “the person” of Oher
column2: which would mean they would have the power to make decisions about healthcare
column3: they also requested that Oher not be allowed to enter into any contracts on his own behalf.

column1: The petition goes on to say that Michael Oher “has no known physical of psychological disabilities.” The petition is signed by the Tuohys
column2: by Oher’s mother and by Oher.

column1: Three months later
column2: without any further pleadings being filed
column3: the judge awarded the Tuohys the ability to make all medical decisions for Oher. His right to enter into contracts was also taken away and given to the Tuohys.

column1: For the next 19 years
column2: the court never required any proof of disability nor did the court require accountings or annual status reports.

column1: This is not how the law of conservatorship works in Tennessee. A court is required to find by clear and convincing evidence
column2: based at least in part on the report of a physician
column3: that the respondent is fully or partially disabled and that he or she is in need of assistance from the court. Rights are then removed from the respondent and vested in the conservator.

column1: Conservatorship system devours dignity:After Britney Spears' abusive conservatorship
column2: don't reform the system – abolish it

column1: There is no “custody” or adoption proceeding that goes along with a conservatorship. The Tuohys could have adopted Oher
column2: even though he had reached 18 years of age. An adoption
column3: however
column4: is fundamentally different than conservatorships and does not remove any rights from a child.

column1: Under Tennessee law
column2: conservators are required to file an accounting and a status report once a year. No accountings or status reports were ever filed in the Oher case.

column1: In August
column3: 19 years later
column4: Michael Oher filed his own petition to terminate the conservatorship and require the Tuohys to account to him.

column1: The Tuohys have filed an answer. They claim that they never told Oher that they were going to adopt him and that their sole motivation in pursuing the conservatorship was to enable Oher to play for the University of Mississippi (“Ole Miss”)
column2: which would have been forbidden under NCAA recruiting rules if they were supporting Oher and he was not a part of their family. They state that they referred to Oher as a son
column3: felt that he was like a son
column4: and “have used that on occasion but not in the legal sense.”

column1: Prison reform gives second chance:First Step Act advanced prison reform
column2: but hundreds are still serving unjust sentences

column1: My very limited research shows that the Tuohys have a book on Amazon for which they are listed as co-authors and which is called: “In a Heartbeat:  Sharing the Power of Cheerful Giving.”  The description of the book refers to the “remarkable couple depicted in ‘The Blind Side’” and the “story of Michael Oher and the family who adopted him.”
The judge over the Oher case in Memphis
column2: Kathleen N. Gomes
column3: entered an order at the end of September terminating the conservatorship but retaining the other issues
column4: i.e.
column5: Oher’s action for accountings and damages.

column1: More will be revealed as this lawsuit progresses
column2: but the case is disturbing. An 18-year-old could be confused by the language of the original petition which refers to guardianship and custody along with conservatorship. Moreover
column3: the Tuohys seem to have profited from the story about adopting Oher in many ways
column4: only one of which may have been financial.

column1: Barbara Moss is founder of Elder Law of Nashville PLC. This column first published in The Commercial Appeal in Memphis
