column1: Many of us have been there before: waking in the middle of the night
column2: often in response to a dream or nightmare
column3: afraid and covered in perspiration.

column1: While sweating has many benefits
column2: such as being a "natural function that the body uses to regulate body temperature
column3:
explains Jewel Kling, MD, assistant director of women's health for Mayo Clinic, it can also be a source of concern. 
For instance, some people worry that their sweat causes body odor, while others fret that their obvious sweating is a sign they're nervous or anxious (which it may well be, but they don't want others to know that). But for people who sweat a lot at night, perspiration can be especially disruptive to a healthy sleep schedule, and even costly due to the amount of laundry it can create. 
Nights sweats are repeated episodes of very excessive sweating that occur during sleep - often heavy enough to soak through nightclothes or bedding, per Mayo Clinic. Such episodes can occur whether one's sleeping environment is hot or cold. 
Night sweats can range from moderate to excessive with drenching sweats
column4:
explains Kling. Like episodes of excessive sweating that can occur during the day, night sweats are usually considered generalized hyperhidrosis, or heavy sweating. Such perspiration can happen on its own or it may be accompanied by an illness such as fever or nausea. 
While various things can cause or contribute to night sweats including medication and medical conditions, it is recommended that when you frequently experience night sweat
column5: you have it evaluated by your clinician to identify the cause
column6:
suggests Kling. 
Another such cause many include hormonal changes like menopause, which can make it hard for the brain to regulate body temperature, often causing night sweat. Infection can contribute as well; as can night terrors or bad dreams. Stress
column7: increased heart rate
column8: and other stimuli can trigger night sweating
column9:
says Anthony Beutler, MD, an associate medical director of sports medicine at Intermountain Health in Salt Lake City.
Other culprits of night sweats include vitamin B12 deficiency, excess weight, dysfunction within the autonomic nervous system or certain disorders of the endocrine system such as thyroid disease. 
And each such factor can lead to different degrees of night sweating. The composition of sweat varies considerably
column10: depending on its cause
column11:
explains Loren Fishman, MD, a professor of physical medicine and rehabilitation at Columbia University.  
It's also worth noting that night sweat is not the same as exercise-related sweat in a couple distinct ways. The chemical composition of perspiration from night sweats
column12: like that from other emotional or endocrine causes
column13: is different in its chemical composition from exercise-induced perspiration
column14:
says Fishman. To explain this, he says that sweat from normal activity is higher in lactate - a product of metabolism - than the sweat produced while sleeping.
Kling adds that night sweat and exercise-related sweat also have different functions, even if the mechanisms that lead to perspiration are similar. Exercise-related sweating is triggered by the body during exercise to control body temperature
column15: she explains. Night sweats are typically caused by something else."

column1: More:Sweating cools us down
column2: but does it burn calories?

column1: If you struggle with blemished or aging skin
column2: or from a skin condition such as acne
column3: chances are you've tried many natural remedies to help. These may have included apple cider vinegar
column4: vitamin supplements
column5: essential oils or even a viral honey and cinnamon mask you may have seen trending on social media.

column1: But chances are
column2: you've also turned to prescription and over-the-counter medications or topical applications in an attempt to find a solution. While there are many products offered by the $146-billion-dollar skin-care industry which include vitamin C serum and a host of lotions and creams
column3: few such products or ingredients are more sought after than retinol.

column1: Retinol is a form of the fat-soluble nutrient vitamin A
column2: and is a popular ingredient in skin cream topicals for its anti-aging effects. It's a type of retinoid - chemical compounds derived from vitamin A or chemically related to it - but is unique in that most retinoids are considered powerful enough to require a prescription while the retinol formula is mild enough to be available in over-the-counter form.

column1: Retinol is most commonly applied topically and only a small amount is needed, explains Dustin Portela
column2: DO
column3: a board-certified dermatologist and founder of Treasure Valley Dermatology in Boise
column4: Idaho. "To my patients
column5: I recommend using a pea-size amount of cream or gel
column6: or about four drops of the serum
column7: to cover the whole face."

column1: Though retinol is mainly used as a lotion
column2: cream
column3: gel or serum
column4: retinol-related medications can be taken orally as well to treat skin conditions and to help "prevent skin cancers in patients at higher risk of skin malignancies
column5:
says Anna Chien, MD, a board-certified dermatologist practicing in Columbia, Maryland, and an associate professor of dermatology at Johns Hopkins School of Medicine.
Retinol is effective in a number of ways. It can unclog pores (and thereby improve acne), neutralize free radicals and exfoliate one's skin. Retinol acts inside your skin cells on several different molecular pathways to help improve the skin's appearance
column6:
explains Portela. In this way, he says it can help boost collagen production and also minimize wrinkles and fine lines. 
Chien says that retinol can also improve skin turnover, decrease the size of sebaceous glands (glands found in hair follicles that secrete the oily substance sebum), even out pigmentation, decrease skin proliferation, improve skin texture and protect against signs of aging. Because of such varied functions, it's used topically for acne
column7: skin aging
column8: discoloration and for certain skin diseases such as psoriasis
column9:
she says. 
While many people reap such benefits without experiencing side effects, retinol does come with some risks
column10: says Portela. He says the most common one is irritation of the skin. It can disrupt the moisture barrier if you use too much or too strong of a retinol for your skin type
column11:
he cautions. 
Another area of concern is that it's possible for retinol to increase one's sensitivity to the sun. Because of this, it is especially important to wear a daily sunscreen if you have incorporated retinol into your skin care routine
column12:
Portela advises. Retinol is also not generally recommended for use while pregnant.
When it comes to decreasing retinol's side effects related to skin irritation, Chien says that can be managed with careful titration of its usage (combined with) a gentle skin care routine."

column1: Acne treatments abound but what work?An expert gets into skincare essentials
Seven months ago
column2: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill student Elizabeth Grace Burton died two days after overdosing on a blend of drugs and alcohol
column3: according to the Assembly
column4: which was the first to report her death this week.

column1: A state autopsy report said Burton
column3: died of a brain injury caused by cardiac arrest following ingestion of a toxic mix of cocaine and alcohol
column4: while a private autopsy also found fentanyl and Gamma-Hydroxybutyric acid (GHB) — a depressant known for its euphoric and calming effects — in Burton’s system. (The state report detected fentanyl in Burton’s urine
column5: but officials did not say it contributed to her death.)

column1: The university’s director of student wellness Dean Blackburn told WUNC last month that three active students and an alum have died of “fentanyl poisoning” in the last two years. The university would not confirm with USA TODAY if Burton was included in that tally.

Fentanyl is a synthetic opioid prescribed for severe pain management. It’s up to 50 times stronger than heroin and 100 times stronger than morphine. Just 2 milligrams — an amount small enough to fit on the tip of a pencil — can be lethal.
Because it’s so potent
column2: fentanyl is often added to other drugs such as cocaine
column3: methamphetamine and heroin
column4: making them cheaper and more dangerous
column5: particularly for teens
column6: college students and other young adults.

column1: “This scenario is sadly not uncommon
column2: and it can happen to anyone
column3: ” said Dr. Ryan Marino
column4: an emergency physician and addiction medicine specialist at University Hospitals Cleveland Medical Center. “This is a reminder of how an unregulated drug supply is always going to be unpredictable and unsafe.”

column1: The best and only way to eliminate the risk of accidental fentanyl exposure is to avoid drugs all together. But Marino says a more realistic piece of advice for those who plan on using them is to "never use alone."
Here are other important things to know.
No. You cannot see
column2: taste or smell any amount of fentanyl in drugs
column3: the CDC says.

column1: Never assume drugs are safe because you know where or who they came from
column2: experts say; your body could also react differently every time you use drugs.

column1: People can use test strips that detect fentanyl in different drugs like cocaine
column2: heroin and methamphetamine
column3: and drug forms
column4: such as pills
column5: powder and injectables
column6: in about five minutes.

column1: It involves dissolving a small amount of a drug in water that you dip a piece of paper in. If the test is positive
column2: throw the drugs out. If it’s negative
column3: be wary because the strips aren't 100% accurate
column4: can’t tell you how much fentanyl is present and can only detect a handful of fentanyl analogs: drugs with similar chemical structures
column5: like the more potent carfentanil.

column1: Still
column2: experts recommend testing drugs anyway. “While they certainly aren’t foolproof
column3: they’re an important tool we have that can reduce harms from an unsafe drug supply
column4: ” Marino said.

column1: Fentanyl test strips are available at your local health department or community organization; they can also be purchased online. Keep in mind
column2: however
column3: that some states consider these tests “criminal drug paraphernalia
column4: ” Marino said.

column1: Symptoms of an opioid overdose include:
If you aren’t sure if a person is high or overdosing
column2: the CDC suggests treating it like an overdose to be safe. Here’s what you should do:

column1: Avoid putting a person suspected of overdosing in a cold shower or bath; hitting them to wake them up; or trying to make them vomit
column2: as that can increase their risk of choking.

column1: And no
column2: you can't overdose on fentanyl just by touching it.

column1: In many cases — no.
Most states have Good Samaritan laws that protect the person who is overdosing or the person who called 911 from certain criminal penalties.
About a year ago
column2: Kristen Sotakoun casually perused her TikTok. She discovered a woman wanting everyone to guess her age. Sotakoun said: I don't need to guess
column3: because I found it on your social media.

column1: The 33-year-old had 30 followers at the time. Now
column2: she has 1.1 million
column3: and regularly posts about "consensual doxxing."

column1: It was total accident, Sotakoun says of her newfound hobby-turned-career of lightly stalking people online. The one-time Chicago restaurant server now makes enough money as a TikTok content creator to produce these videos full-time.
People have criticized her for the term she made up. There's nothing "consensual" about doxxing
column2: when you publicly expose someone's personal information (such as a home address or phone number) in order to cause harm. But that's just it: she's facetious. Sotakoun doesn't jump down the rabbit holes of the internet on a quest to find someone's birthday unless they specifically ask (hence the "consensual" part).

column1: Think of her as TikTok's Nancy Drew. "I look at it like a puzzle
column2: and I've always loved puzzles
column3: she says, and also wants to educate people about their online presence. Experts say consensual doxxing" can be a useful tool for learning about how much information you've put out online about yourself or can simply be a fun activity – but consider it a cautionary tale
column4: too.

column1: While people on TikTok aren't doing anything malicious with the information, people with intent to harass or harm could pick up doxxing techniques from these videos, says Kimberly Vered Shashoua
column2: licensed clinical social worker. "Unfortunately
column3: these videos highlight an uncomfortable truth: our lives are way more exposed online than we'd like to imagine."

column1: The first TikTok Sotakoun made about "consensual doxxing
column2:
only one person commented. After her second video: Hundreds of comments per day. That number has held steady – she picks one or two out of these leads per day to pursue – partially because of the effort she puts into the task.
It's evolved into people wanting to see the most creative way I found it
column3:
she says.
In her first viral video, for example, the subject in question had no videos, his profile picture had a cartoon filter over his face and the only remarkable attribute was that he was wearing glasses. She dug deep through his followers to find a family member, scrolled through her likes on Facebook and found someone else's profile picture where a man was wearing glasses. It correlated with a comment he made on TikTok about being an engineer, and that he lived in Florida, and so on.
For many people
column4: consensual doxxing is like a treasure hunt
column5: Vered Shashoua says. While making waves on TikTok
column6: consensual doxxing has been a form of entertainment for awhile
column7: such as in shows like 'Catfish.'"

column1: Sotakoun is not perfect. Sometimes it's impossible to find people's birthdays when their profile is private
column2: they have no followers
column3: they follow no one and/or their username just has the word "user" and a bunch of numbers.

column1: Obviously, I cannot do anything with that, she says. She estimates she finds 70% to 80% of the people whose birthdays she looks up.
A note about the method to her madness: She doesn't use public records
column2: just social media.

column1: I want to try to show you that info that you have provided, is the reason that I found your birthday, even though you think you're locked down, your digital footprint is not as good as you think, she says.
Brad Fulton
column2: associate professor of management and social policy at the Indiana University – Bloomington
column3: adds: "It’s important for people to know how much of their personal information can be found online
column4: and consensual doxxing can provide a relatively safe way for someone to discover the extent of their online exposure."

column1: In case you missed:'Dimple maker' trend is taking over TikTok
column2: but could it cause permanent damage?

column1: Sometimes people reach out asking her for tasks beyond birthdays – like to help solve cases. While flattering
column2: she leaves that up to crime-fighting professionals.

column1: Everybody has the FBI friend of the group. But TikTok has really shown me that hey, I think maybe I'm pretty good at this, she says.
Of course
column2: people may take the wrong lessons away from these videos (i.e. doxxing someone for real). But the positive response has outweighed the negative for Sotakoun.

column1: I'm hoping that it reaches people who are looking to be more private on the internet, she says. "I'm hoping that the greater good is happening here
column2: and that people will watch my videos and say
column3: 'oh
column4: I need to follow these methods so I can be more protected myself on the internet' as opposed to people using it for more nefarious purposes."

column1: Interesting:A TikToker went viral for blaming being late to work on 'time blindness.' Is it a real thing?
Time to be blunt. James Patterson is less author and more writing machine.
If the onetime ad director turned commercial fiction juggernaut were not decidedly made of flesh and blood
column2: it would be easy to argue that he is actually the humanoid name for ChatGPT
column3: though with much better composition. Send the James Patterson 8000 machine a story idea and
column4: presto
column5: a plot-twisting bestseller emerges.

column1: But the truth of his staggering success – around 200 books and a net worth reported above $800 million – is far simpler. Other than playing early morning golf with his wife Sue
column2: he’d rather be at the laptop hammering out words.

column1: “I came across a quote recently that relates to us all
column2: which is
column3: ‘My time here is short
column4: what can I do most beautifully?’” Patterson says during a conversation with USA TODAY. “For me
column5: that is telling stories. And there are different ways to do that. And I do think I’m a good partner in that pursuit. I don’t bring a big ego to it.”

column1: Collaboration is not a word often associated with writers. Many prefer the solitary if agonizing pursuit of word craft. Or
column2: as the fabled sportswriter Red Smith once described writing: It is merely sitting at a typewriter and opening up a vein.

column1: Check out: USA TODAY's weekly Best-selling Booklist
But Patterson welcomes the assist. To date
column2: he has co-written books with nearly two dozen people
column3: some fellow pros such as Maxine Paetro and Michael Ledwidge
column4: and others more bold faced names such as former President Bill Clinton and Dolly Parton. And he will soon drop a new book with a “wonderful actor who everyone loves.” He won’t say more. (We're hoping it's Tom Hanks
column5: whose debut novel
column6: “The Making of Another Major Motion Picture Masterpiece
column7:
proved he's as gifted bringing characters to life on the page as he is on the screen.)
For Patterson, the art of collaboration is the natural human state. The idea surfaced first in the mid-‘90s, when he and pal Peter de Jonge finished a round of golf and started talking about a story idea and the next thing they knew, they were writing up “Miracle on the 17th Green.”
“So much good stuff comes from collaboration, most TV shows and movies are all collaboration,” he says. “And if we’re going to save the planet, that’ll take collaboration.”
Patterson’s latest teamwork opus is part one of a planned trilogy with Mike Lupica called “12 Months to Live,” featuring a hard-nosed criminal defense attorney who has that exact life expectancy. The duo is done with “8 Months to Live” and honing in on “4 Months to Live,” writing as fiercely as if they also had the Grim Reaper at their door.
“We have a great writers’ room over the telephone Mike and I, we talk six or seven times a day,” says Patterson. “That’s how we work, and we’ve become best friends along the way.”
Asked how the ideas come, and Patterson relates a story so improbable it can only be true. He said he and Lupica were on a recent book tour in New Jersey and while out for a stroll the weather turned nasty. As they hustled back to shelter, they passed an old man battling the rain on a bicycle.
“I saw the guy, I waved, and a word came out,” he says, not sharing what word. “I went inside and wrote five pages, and that’s going to be our next book together. I’m not sure if that’s a gift or a curse.”
While Patterson’s working relationship with Lupica, a prize-winning sportswriter turned novelist, is on the idyllic side, others don’t work out as well.
Without naming names, Patterson is frank. “Disasters? Yes, in the last two years I’ve had three books where I had to go re-write the whole thing,” he says. “I’m seeing drafts every few weeks and suddenly you see, it’s not happening.”
But most do “happen.” He says his interactions with Clinton (they co-wrote 2018’s “The President Is Missing” and 2021’s “The President’s Daughter”) were smooth, with the Florida-based author shuttling chapters to the former president in New York.
“He’s very smart and a good writer,” says Patterson. “Often a writer is making things up, but in this case, I didn’t have to wonder what the Secret Service would do, I could ask him.” Clinton often would send back chapters with voluminous notes, and the two managed to match their writing styles enough so that the end result was not disjointed.
When it came to working with singing and acting icon Parton (2022’s “Run, Rose, Run”), Patterson again mined his co-author’s real life story to forge a tale of a young singer-songwriter on the rise and on the run from her past.
“For her, it came from the heart,” he says. “But besides that, we have very similar work ethics, although she gets up at 4 a.m. and gets to work, she’s crazy. I gave her an outline, and two days later she had notes and seven songs written. That was the spirit of that thing.”
Generally speaking, Patterson says he comes up with a story synopsis which gets shared with collaborators who then weigh in with their own thoughts and ideas. Then comes a very detailed outline, which is critical to Patterson’s process.
As for the actual writing, it depends on the collaborator. Those with extensive writing chops get less oversight, where newcomers require Patterson to spend more time with the manuscript.
But he’s not complaining. He said he’s been working seven days a week since he was a teen, and finds nothing more satisfying that telling tales, alone or with others. He doesn’t do big cocktails parties, too phony; he prefers the intimacy of a night out chatting with another couple.
There are the morning golf outings with Sue, often embarked upon so early the grounds crew is still on the course. “So we just pick up our balls and walk on,” he says. “We’re back home by 8 a.m.” And then it’s back to the keyboard.
“I don’t have writer’s block, I have writer’s diarrhea,” jokes the man who has published millions of words. “But every time I start something, I am always hoping that the next book is the best thing I’ve ever done.”

column1: Spoiler alert! This story includes detailed plot points of the new movie "Killers of the Flower Moon" and the real-life events on which it's based.

column2: brimming with deceit and death in 1920s Oklahoma.

column1: The 3-hour-and 26-minute film
column2: starring Robert De Niro
column3: Leonardo DiCaprio and Lily Gladstone
column4: tells the story of Osage Nation tribal members
column5: newly wealthy from the discovery of oil on their otherwise parched reservation lands
column6: and the duplicitous non-Native Americans who swoop in to steal their bounty.

column1: But while it plays like an allegory
column2: the story is true. Based on the best-selling 2017 book by journalist David Grann
column3: “Killers” is the result of years of research and interviews with Osage elders. The tale explored both the deaths surrounding the family of Mollie Burkhart (Gladstone) as well as the exploits of the nascent Federal Bureau of Investigation.

column1: USA TODAY spoke with Grann to get details on how the movie compares with his book.
“Absolutely
column2: ” says Grann. “Because of the vast oil deposits on their lands
column3: by the 1920s the Osage were among the wealthiest people per capita in the world.”

column1: People of the Osage Nation had been moved around by the federal government for years before winding up in a barren stretch of Oklahoma
column2: which wasn’t worth much at the turn of the 20th century. But when oil deposits were discovered
column3: everything changed.

column1: Grann says that in 1923
column2: with roughly 2
column3: 000 people on the tribal rolls
column4: the group “collectively got more than $30 million (in payments from oil companies leasing their land)
column5: ” which translates to about $500 million in today's dollars. And while “few Americans owned a car at that time
column6: many Osage had numerous cars
column7: as well as many servants
column8: often white.”

column1: ‘Maybe we’re all capable of this’:Martin Scorsese on ‘Killers of the Flower Moon’ movie
Grann says at least 24 Osage tribal members were murdered in order to get their oil rights
column2: so-called “headrights.” A typical way to get these rights was marrying into an Osage family. But as the book and movie explain
column3: sometimes there were shootings or slow poisonings to make the deaths look like mysterious ailments.

column1: While the “Killers” movie focuses on the evil schemes of one man
column2: William Hale (DeNiro)
column3: and his hapless nephew Ernest Burkhart (DiCaprio)
column4: “the real murders were less about a singular plot or evil figure with henchmen
column5: but rather many killings that were never properly investigated. Many people were complicit: Doctors with their poison
column6: morticians covering up causes of death
column7: lawmen staying silent. Many conclude the real death toll was in the scores
column8: if not hundreds.”

column1: Not likely
column2: says Grann. “There is no evidence that I know of that Mollie spoke to the president about the murders
column3: ” he says. “But it needs to be underscored that the Osage did go to Washington
column4: D.C.
column5: and she might have been on a trip.”

column1: Grann says Burkhart
column2: as the movie shows
column3: was so distraught by the deaths of her sisters that she “vigorously campaigned for justice
column4: offering testimony when needed and hiring private detectives to help find the killers.”

column2: a young J. Edgar Hoover
column3: who would wind up as the notorious and longstanding director of the FBI
column4: took over a new office then simply called the Bureau of Investigation. Hoover was eager to put his new group on the political map
column5: so he eagerly dispatched a former Texas Ranger
column6: Tom White (Jesse Plemons) to Oklahoma to investigate the mysterious Osage murders after local law enforcement hadn't solved the case.

column1: “This was among the first big complex homicide investigations by the fledgling Bureau of Investigation
column2: which would become the FBI
column3: ” says Grann. “At the time
column4: this office had limited jurisdiction over crimes nationally
column5: but it did have jurisdiction over crimes on federal (Native American) lands.”

column1: Grann adds that thanks in part to this case
column2: laws were passed in the 1930s that gave the FBI greater reach.

column1: “There was something unquestionably evil about Hale
column2: at his core
column3: ” says Grann. “According to the records he did show no remorse. He had created and was reflective of a pathological ideology of western expansionism
column4: a boosterism and a conviction' that the Native American way of life was ending. world was going.”

column1: Hale served his time and died at 87 in Arizona in 1962.

column1: “Hoover wanted it to burnish his and the Bureau’s reputation

column1: This is the 20-year anniversary of the Marlins’ stunning World Series championship

column1: He cringes about what is happening in Miami. He believes that Jeter ruined the ballpark by removing their home run sculpture behind the center-field fence. He wonders what owner Bruce Sherman is doing after firing so many of his employees

column1: So much for the good vibes of a 20-year reunion.
Really
column2: it all started when Loria
column3: on the advice of traveling secretary Bill Beck
column4: hired McKeon
column5: who had been out of baseball for three years. The Marlins were 16-22
column6: Loria wanted to fire Jeff Torborg

column1: “So I called him
column2: told me to meet on Collins Avenue
column3: and there is an older gentleman sitting there with a plaid shirt and different plaid pants
column4:
Loria says. “I said, 'Jack?' He said, 'Jerry?’ 
And that’s how our beautiful relationship started."

column1: McKeon led the Marlins to a wild-card berth back at a time where there was only one wild card team
column2: beat the San Francisco Giants in the NL Division Series
column3: shocked the Cubs after trailing 3 games to 1
column4: and then turned the baseball world upside down by beating the Yankees with a payroll three times the size of Miami.

column1: “It’s something I’ll cherish forever
column2: Loria says. “I can still see almost every play, every innings, all of the excitement in Chicago to hearing Pudge Rodriguez say, 'We’re going to win this one for you, Jack.'

column1: It was Rodriguez
column2: the Hall of Fame catcher
column3: along with several players

column1: “Just win the [expletive] World Series
column2: ’’ Loria said

column1: What they didn’t realize was that Loria
column2: the art dealer
column3: would design a ring that would forever change sports. The ring weighed a stunning 100.6 grams with the gem weight of 4.75 carats
column4: including 228 white diamonds.

column1: It wasn’t so much a ring
column2: but a portable trophy.

column1: “I was the art dealer trying to create something great
column2:
Loria said. “I wanted it to be special, I wanted it to be sculptural. I said, 'Boys, you’re going to get the biggest, greatest thing you ever saw, but just win the damn World Series.'
“Now, as you notice, it changed championship rings, with that tremendous, big style, in all of sports.’’ 
It never would have been possible, Loria says, if not for the hiring of McKeon and the call-up of 20-year-old Cabrera. He was playing at Class AA, strictly as a third baseman, and the Marlins needed an outfielder. Loria suggested Cabrera, which was shot down by GM Larry Beinfest. 
“I told him he had no choice, Cabrera came up, hit a walk-off homer in the 10th inning, and that was the start of his Hall of Fame career.

column1: It was in the World Series against the Yankees that Loria decided to exercise his authority again. He was on the bench during batting practice before Game 1
column2: and noticed that the Marlins were awestruck by Yankee Stadium
column3: a fear that they didn’t belong.

column2: “I think we have a problem. They’re playing Frank Sinatra’s 'New York
column3: New York.’ My players are coming in from center field where they were in Monument Park
column4: looking over at the Yankee dugout

column1: So
column2: Loria asked McKeon if he could address the team.

column1: McKeon’s response: “It’s your [expletive] team
column2: Jeffrey. You’re the owner. You can do what you want.’’

column1: Loria walked into the clubhouse carrying a baseball bat
column2: picked up the bat
column3: and smashed it on the table.

column1: “Look
column2: you’ve got the best record in baseball the second half of the season
column3:
Loria shouted. “You’ve got a leader in your manager. If you believe in him and yourself, you will the Series. 
“Oh, and just to let know, all of those players’ names you saw in Monument Park are dead.

column1: Loria interjected himself one more time before the Series was over after McKeon decided to start ace Josh Beckett on short rest. It was a huge risk. McKeon could have waited until Game 7 with Beckett on regular rest

column2: knowing that Beckett

column2: “Josh

column1: “Well
column2: I walk into the stadium late that afternoon

column1: Beckett threw a five-hit

column1: “Jack is my hero

“But to be a baseball owner again? No, thank you. I’ve had enough. I’ve got the memories, and no one can ever take that away.

column1: Hall of Fame pitcher Pedro Martinez is imploring Dominican Republic officials and Major League Baseball to increase their security to stop the rage of armed robberies at baseball’s academies in the Dominican Republic.

column2: Miami Marlins
column3: Cleveland Guardians and Detroit Tigers_who have been victimized by armed robberies. The Dominican Republic police is searching for men who have entered the complexes with gun to steal cash

column1: “This has become really dangerous

Martinez told USA TODAY Sports. “It’s become alarming and concerning, not to just MLB, but all of us. We send our kids to these academies, feel like they’re protected, and things are happening. 
“I don’t know what is happening, or what is leading to this, but it needs to be stopped by the authorities in the Dominican Republic quickly so it does not escalate. MLB needs to also get involved to give more protection for these kids and those who work in the academies.

column1: “This never used to happen when I was back in the academy in the Dominican with the Dodgers

Martinez said. “We didn’t come from anything. There was not one player who was middle or upper class. But because we played baseball, we were spoiled. We were treated like royalty. We were untouchable. 
“We came from the same areas, the same ghettos as the people that are robbing these players. No one touched us. I don’t know what’s going on, but it needs to be addressed.

column1: If you're thinking of taking a cruise soon

column2: 000 berths to 746
column4: you don't want to make a rookie mistake.

column1: The last thing you need is to miss the cruise and then have to get to the next port, said Limor Decter
column2: a luxury travel advisor with EMBARK Beyond. "No one needs that kind of drama."

column1: There are no publicly available statistics on the number of passengers who miss their cruise because of airline connections. But based on the number of cases I've received lately
column2: it seems to be a growing problem. Passengers don't think about it soon enough
column3: that's true
column4: but cruise lines also impose significant restrictions on their air-inclusive programs.

column1: Booking airline tickets through your cruise line may seem like a good deal
column2: because they often offer guarantees that you will make it to your ship even if your flight is delayed.

column1: There are other benefits. The special contract fares offered through cruise lines are sometimes cheaper than published airfares. The cruise line air programs also often allow you to hold flight reservations until the final payment date. You can change flights at any time before making your final payment. You can't easily do that if you book directly with the airline.
But there are also some downsides – which is to say
column2: some restrictions apply. After Debra Stewart missed her recent Norwegian Cruise Line (NCL) cruise because of a flight cancellation
column3: she found out that the Booksafe Travel Protection Plan had a few strings attached. NCL would only offer a future cruise credit equal to 75% of the non-refundable cancellation charge because her flight cancellation was not covered under the Booksafe plan. She said that cost her $16

column1: I checked with NCL
column2: and it said the policy had been applied correctly to her Booksafe Protection Plan.

column1: Although Norwegian Cruise Line provides flight arrangements as part of its cruise offering, we do not have control over the operations of the airlines and are not responsible for any flight modifications or cancelations, a spokesman told me
column2: adding that its claim assessments "are final."

column1: NCL noted that under its Booksafe Travel Protection Plan
column2: it will provide guests who are denied due to a non-covered reason with a future cruise credit equal to 75% of the non-refundable cancellation charge to use on your next cruise and that it had done so in this case.

column1: This is so wrong, said Stewart

column3: California. "They canceled the flight
column4: I missed my cruise – and I am out $16

column1: Visa-free travel for short-term visits to the U.S. for Israelis is now available.
Israel officially became part of the U.S. Visa Waiver Program on Thursday
column2: which allows eligible Israeli citizens and nationals to travel to the U.S. for up to 90 days on business or tourism without having to first obtain a visa.

column1: The admittance came earlier than estimated. On Sept. 27
column2: when admittance to VWP was announced

column1:
Israel’s entry into the Visa Waiver Program represents a critical step forward in our strategic partnership with Israel that will further strengthen long-standing people-to-people engagement, economic cooperation, and security coordination between our two countries,” Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said in a Sept. 27 statement.
The VWP requires the person looking to come to the U.S. sans visa to be from a country that extends to U.S. citizens and nationals the privileges we would extend to their citizens and nationals
column2:
according to a DHS press release.
Learn more: Best travel insurance
More:US airlines suspend flights to Israel as State Department urges caution
People can apply for the program via the U.S. Customs and Border Protection’s (CBP) Electronic System for Travel Authorization (ESTA) or via its mobile app. Approval may take up to 72 hours.
To be eligible for VWP, Israeli citizens and nationals must have a biometrically enabled passport book. Currently, the application is only available in English, but other languages are slated to come on Nov. 1.
The change comes as the conflict continues to build in the Middle East. The death toll of Israelis and Palestinians surpassed 5,000 on Thursday, becoming the deadliest war on the Gaza Strip.
Kathleen Wong is a travel reporter for USA TODAY based in Hawaii. You can reach her at kwong@usatoday.com.
Amsterdam will increase its tourist tax in 2024 in a continued effort to crack down on rowdy tourists. The new rate will be the highest in Europe and the fourth highest globally.
The new tax rate for overnight visitors will be 12.5%, up substantially from 7%, according to an announcement by the city earlier this month.
The more expensive tax means tourists will be contributing more to the very city they're enjoying.
This allows us to address the consequences of overtourism and direct additional resources to keeping the streets clean and solving acute problems in neighbourhoods and districts
column3:
Hester van Buren, deputy mayor for finance, said in a statement.
More:Why Amsterdam wants tourists to 'stay away'
Learn more: Best travel insurance
With the average room rate of €175 ($185.32), this translates to a €21.80 ($23.09) per night tax. Currently, the tax would be €15.25 ($16.03).
Cruise passengers will also be paying more too. The current tax is €8 ($8.41), and it's slated to go up to €11 ($11.56) per person per day.
By increasing the tourist tax, the city said it won't raise parking fees or property tax rates for its residents, according to the announcement. The tourist tax revenue will go directly into enhancing Amsterdam neighborhoods, such as growing the city's green spaces.
Next up on the to-do list is finding a way to tax day-trippers, van Buren told DutchNews.
The city's ongoing battle between troublesome tourists and locals goes back years. In 2019, the city banned guided tours in the Red Light District and this past March, launched a Stay Away" campaign.

column1: Amsterdam isn't the only city making travelers pay for their share. A few weeks ago
column2: Iceland announced a tourist tax that would help protect its natural resources
column3: which are a main draw for visitors. So did Venice and Bali. Even places in the U.S. charge a tourist tax. In Honolulu
column4: travelers have to pay a total of 13.25% for their accommodations
column5: and that money supports services like lifeguards and hiking trail maintenance.

UPDATE: This story has been updated with news that within hours of publication of USA TODAY's investigation

column1: Two years ago
column2: one of the nation’s star college football coaches and a prominent rape survivor teamed up to fight the culture of sexual violence in sports.

column1: Their partnership should have been a force for good. Instead
column2: it has devolved into scandal
column3: with the activist accusing the coach of the same misconduct that both of them preached against.

column1: The accused is Mel Tucker
column2: the head football coach at Michigan State University and one of the highest paid coaches in all of sports. Accusing him is Brenda Tracy
column3: a rape survivor who has made educating athletes about sexual violence her life’s work.

column1: Over eight months
column2: they developed a professional relationship centered on her advocacy work. Tucker invited Tracy to campus three times – twice to speak to his players and staff and once to be recognized as an honorary captain at the team's spring football game.

column1: But their relationship was upended during a phone call on April 28
column3: Tracy says in a complaint she filed with the university’s Title IX office in December that remains under investigation.

column1: According to her complaint
column2: Tracy sat frozen for several minutes while Tucker made sexual comments about her and masturbated. His violation
column3: she said
column4: reopened 25-year-old wounds from her rape by four men – two Oregon State University football players
column5: a junior college player and a high school recruit.

column1: “The idea that someone could know me and say they understand my trauma but then re-inflict that trauma on me is so disgusting to me
column2: it’s hard for me to even wrap my mind around it
column3: ” she told USA TODAY. “It’s like he sought me out just to betray me.”

column1: In his statements to the Title IX investigator
column2: Tucker acknowledged masturbating on the call but said Tracy grossly mischaracterized the episode. According to him
column3: they had consensual “phone sex.”

column1: “Ms. Tracy’s distortion of our mutually consensual and intimate relationship into allegations of sexual exploitation has really affected me
column2: ” Tucker wrote in a March 22 letter to the investigator. “I am not proud of my judgment and I am having difficulty forgiving myself for getting into this situation
column3: but I did not engage in misconduct by any definition.”

column1: Michigan State hired an outside Title IX attorney to investigate the complaint. She finished her investigation in July. A formal hearing to determine whether Tucker violated the school’s policy banning sexual harassment and exploitation is scheduled for Oct. 5 and 6
column2: during the Spartans’ bye week.

column1: The stakes are high for everyone.

Tracy says Tucker is following through on a threat to ruin her career and reputation by painting her as a woman who mixes professional and personal relationships and files false reports. She fears he will undo her legacy.
Tucker
column2: who signed one of the most lucrative contracts in college sports history two years ago

column4: which would be a stunning fall from the elite ranks of college coaches.

column1: Reached by USA TODAY on his cellphone Saturday night

column1: Hours after USA TODAY published its investigation

column3: pending a resolution of the Title IX case.

column1: “This step
column2: suspending Mel Tucker without pay
column3: is … necessary and appropriate for today's circumstances
column4: ” Interim President Teresa Woodruff said at a Sunday evening press conference. “These actions are not taken lightly.”

column1: USA TODAY typically does not identify people who allege sexual harassment. Tracy agreed to be identified and shared more than 1

column1: Title IX
column2: the federal law banning sex discrimination in education
column3: requires schools to investigate allegations of sexual harassment that took place in the context of a school program or activity. Such claims are inherently difficult to adjudicate because of many of the factors at issue in this case: a lack of eyewitnesses and recordings
column4: the passage of time and the thorniness of litigating consent.

column1: Adding to the uncertainty
column2: the institution tasked with sorting out the facts is perhaps best known for missing repeated opportunities to stop one of the most prolific sexual abusers in American history.

column1: For nearly two decades
column2: Michigan State leaders failed to act on complaints against Larry Nassar
column3: the disgraced former U.S.A. Gymnastics and campus physician accused of sexually assaulting more than 300 female athletes under the guise of medical treatments. He has been sentenced to a minimum of 100 years in prison.

column1: Amid its efforts to rebuild trust among students
column2: employees
column3: alumni and the East Lansing community
column4: Michigan State's leaders must now decide whether the face of its prestigious football program is guilty of sexually harassing one of the country’s most influential advocates against gender-based violence.

column1: For some
column2: how the university navigates the crisis will send a clear message about its commitment to progress.

column1: “This goes beyond coach Tucker and Brenda Tracy
column2: ” said Jennifer Gomez
column3: a Boston University professor who researches the effects of interpersonal trauma and violence. “What happens here has the potential to be very healing or very harmful for lots and lots and lots of other people.”

column1: Tracy and Tucker met in August 2021 during her first visit to Michigan State

column1: Standing before a packed auditorium in the Spartans’ football operations building

Tucker sat down for his interview on March 22.

column1: In the absence of eyewitnesses or recordings

column1: In multiple cases she has worked

column4: and they could sway the case in Tracy’s favor.
