Transformative Experiences” is a seven-part series focusing on how travel can change the lives of those open to the experiences that new places can bring. If you'd like to contribute to our future reporting and share your experience as a source, you can click here to fill out this quick form.
One of the main reasons I was offered this opportunity was that no one else wanted to do it.
It was April 2020. The pandemic had just started, and all of a sudden, I was considered an “essential worker” being asked to travel the country. Normally, the idea of traveling sparks images of exploring fun restaurants and unique places, meeting up with friends or family, or getting to know new people – none of this was even an option. Most businesses were closed. The idea of even booking a hotel was difficult because every city, county, and state had different regulations as to who was allowed to be there. Everyone I knew was staying at home and enjoying a small circle of people to quarantine with while I was getting to leave the house and experience new places.
I thought I had beat the system!
Making my way up the coast was breathtakingly beautiful. I had wrapped up my work in California and was driving up the Pacific Coast Highway, with a pit stop at Redwoods National Park planned the next day on the way to Oregon. The night was getting late, and I needed to find a spot to sleep, so I booked a hotel on my phone and pulled into the small military town of Fort Bragg. I grabbed my bag and, half asleep, wandered into the hotel to check-in. 
Learn more: Best travel insurance
“Checking in?” the guy at the motel asked. 
“Yes, I have a reservation.” I handed him my ID. 
“Are you working in town?” 
“Yes sir, I just finished and am on my way north.”
“I need proof that you have a job in town, or unfortunately, you won’t be allowed to stay here,” he said. 
“I did have a job. I finished it before checking in,” I explained, showing him my work order. 
“Unfortunately, if you don’t have work here tomorrow, it would be against the law for you to stay here.” I was sent away. Mendocino County did not want me to stay the night, apparently, so I had to sleep in my car tucked off of the highway instead. 
How I scaled Patagonia with ALS:'The right wheelchair will take you anywhere a pair of legs can'
I was completely alone and isolated. The excitement of traveling was quickly wearing off.
That rip current sign was in my head again. It said, “If you need help, yell or wave for assistance.” Only spending time with myself was going to be the greatest challenge I had ever faced. Most people have family and friends surrounding them in these moments of life transition. Everyone I knew was miles and miles away, self-isolating with their loved ones. 
Making my way north through Portland and Seattle, I discovered that artists in nearly every city put murals up on the plywood that businesses used to board up their buildings. Everywhere I went, there were more plywood murals, and I started taking photos of them in every city. It gave me something to take my mind off of having to be my own best friend and attempting to enjoy my own company. 
The pandemic made so many great cities look like empty, post-apocalyptic shells of themselves. They were depressed, empty, and dangerous. They looked like how I felt inside. As society was going through a difficult transition, so was I. But these murals were something else, a sign of hope. I began to see them as a sign that even in moments of transition, we can still make the best of things and create something beautiful.
My creativity had long been in hibernation. I had bought a camera a few years prior in an attempt to share a hobby with my wife, who was always setting up elaborate photoshoots. I didn't even really know how to use my camera, but I began experimenting, walking around these abandoned cities and capturing this historical moment in time. I couldn’t help but wonder if these cities would ever return to their former glory.
Would they be better than they were before? Was there a chance that everything, including my life, would be better in the future? 
This is an excerpt from “Going Places: Soul-Stirring Essays About the Travel That Changed Us,” published on Sept. 22 by Sulit Press. Author Jason Fuerstenberg has been an independent travel writer and photographer for over five years based out of California.
CORALVILLE — U.S. Rep. Mariannette Miller-Meeks, standing on the bed of a bright red truck, delivered a passionate defense of her votes opposing U.S. Rep. Jim Jordan's bid for House speaker — a high-profile break from the majority of House Republicans that she said spawned death threats against her.
“I am never going to quit fighting for Iowa, and I am never going to quit fighting for this country, Miller-Meeks yelled at her annual fundraiser event Friday night. "So if you think you can intimidate me
column2: go … suck it up
column3: buttercup!"

column1: Washington
column2: D.C.
column3: was gridlocked this week as House Republicans failed to elect a new speaker. The caucus nominated Jordan
column4: an ultraconservative representative from Ohio.

column1: In the first round of votes
column2: Miller-Meeks and the other three members in Iowa's delegation cast their votes for Jordan — but holdouts from 20 Republicans tanked Jordan's bid. Miller-Meeks explained Friday that she voted to Jordan out of respect for a House rule that members vote on the floor for whoever gets the majority vote in a closed-door conference.

column1: But
column2: she told reporters
column3: she had concerns about whether Jordan could unify the party
column4: and she was worried about the looming threat of a government shutdown.

column1: I wanted assurances that Republican members of Congress were not going to be attacking other Republicans, Miller-Meeks said. "As soon as the vote was had in conference
column2: and then
column3: not two hours later
column4: we had that coming out."

column1: In the second round of votes on Wednesday
column2: Miller-Meeks withdrew her support for Jordan. She cast her vote Wednesday for U.S. Rep. Kay Granger of Texas
column3: a Republican who chairs the Appropriations Committee.

column1: Since my vote in support of Chairwoman Granger, I have received credible death threats and a barrage of threatening calls, Miller-Meeks said in a statement Wednesday night. "The proper authorities have been notified and my office is cooperating fully."
On Friday
column2: Jordan lost a third floor vote for speaker
column3: with Iowa's delegation voting for him except for Miller-Meeks. Jordan then lost a secret ballot and withdrew his nomination.

column1: Miller-Meeks did not mention the death threats specifically during her speech Friday
column2: but she delivered a passionate defense of her Congressional record.

column1: “I’m not a Democrat. I am a proud Republican
column2: Miller-Meeks said. Why do I want to get appropriations bills across? … It’s because every one of those appropriations bills has Republican priorities and Republican policies."

column1: Miller-Meeks thanked her office staff for dealing with a "very stressful week." She anticipates House Republicans will successfully choose a speaker "next week."

We had a vote for speaker, and then I had to rush here to make my own tailgate. And so, there are candidates who have thrown their name into the ring, Miller-Meeks told reporters. "I have told everybody I’m not doing anything until Sunday."
Katie Akin is a politics reporter for the Register. Reach her atkakin@registermedia.com. Follow her on Twitter at @katie_akin.
Imagine a young married couple. One partner invests heavily in his employer’s 401(k)
column2: saving for both spouses. The other focuses on paying the bills and contributes nothing to her retirement plan
column3: missing out on the employer's matching funds.

column1: That was how Niv Persaud and her husband handled their finances.
“My income was going toward our expenses
column2: and he was going to focus on retirement
column3: ” she said. “And I had a great company match
column4: and I didn’t pay attention to that.”

column1: The marriage eventually ended. Three decades later
column2: Persaud works as a certified financial planner in Atlanta. Her lost retirement savings provide a cautionary tale.

column1: How much potential savings did she lose?
Protect your assets: Best high-yield savings accounts of 2023
“I don’t even want to think about it
column2: ” she said.

column1: In fact
column2: one in four married couples fails to take full advantage of employers who make matching contributions to 401(k) retirement plans
column3: a recent study found. The oversight costs them nearly $700 a year
column4: on average.

column1: Nearly two-thirds of American workers have access to an employer-sponsored defined contribution retirement savings plan
column2: according to the paper
column3: titled “Efficiency in Household Decision Making: Evidence from the Retirement Savings of U.S. Couples
column4: ” and released in April by the National Bureau of Economic Research.

column1: Most plans offer a match: The employer contributes to a 401(k)
column2: matching some or all of the funds paid into the plan by the worker. In one typical model
column3: the employer matches half of every dollar a worker contributes
column4: up to a maximum of 6% of the worker’s pay.

column1: The study found that about 24% of married couples left money on the table by failing to claim some of an employer’s matching funds. Those couples lost $682 a year
column2: on average
column3: money they could recover simply by changing the allocation of their retirement contributions. The findings are based on IRS tax data and retirement plan descriptions.

column1: “There’s a lot of advice around
column2: ‘You should save more
column3: ’” said Taha Choukhmane
column4: an assistant professor of finance at the MIT Sloan School of Management. “It’s not just how much you save. It’s how you save
column5: and where you save.”

column1: Choukhmane co-authored the working paper with Cormac O’Dea
column2: an assistant professor of economics at Yale
column3: and Lucas Goodman
column4: an economist at the Treasury Department.

column1: The researchers stressed that their focus was not on couples that don’t save for retirement
column2: or don’t save enough. Instead
column3: they looked at couples that could increase their savings merely by shifting contributions from one spouse to the other.

column1: “You don’t need to save more. You don’t need to change how you spend
column2: ” Choukhmane said. “It’s all about how you allocate money across accounts.”

column1: In some couples
column2: the researchers found
column3: only one spouse contributed to a retirement plan
column4: while the other ignored a plan with a generous employer match. Other couples split retirement savings equally when they should have put more money into an account with a larger match.

column1: “The 401(k) is really designed around individuals
column2: ” Choukhmane said. “And I think a lot of people need to realize that this is not about the individual.”

column1: The new study underscores a lack of cooperation between spouses on an important matter of household finance. The researchers said it also speaks to the broader issue of financial communication in marriage.
“It does open up a question of what other big decisions couples are not coordinating on
column2: ” O’Dea
column3: the assistant professor at Yale
column4: said.

column1: The researchers found that couples that had been married longer
column2: and couples with children
column3: tended to do a better job at communicating and coordinating retirement savings. Couples in shorter relationships did worse.

column1: Couples headed for divorce were also less likely to coordinate their retirement contributions. The researchers discovered this by studying the saving patterns of marriages that ended in divorce.
Investment advisers often recommend that American workers save 10% to 15% of their pre-tax income for retirement. They also urge them to max out any matching funds from the employer
column2: which boosts the worker’s effective savings rate.

column1: If a company matches up to 6% of your salary in 401(k) contributions
column2: "maxing out" means contributing at least that much of your annual pay.

column1: “The first priority for any investor should be to save enough to get at least the entire employer match
column2: ” said Rob Williams
column3: managing director of financial planning at Charles Schwab.

column1: Yet
column2: many partners leave the money untapped. Vanguard
column3: for example
column4: reports that 31% of its retirement plan participants failed to claim some or all of an employer’s matching funds in 2022.

column1: Retirement savings rates are lower for younger workers
column2: whose retirement falls in the more distant future. Among Vanguard participants
column3: the retirement savings rate in 2022 ranged from 5.2% for workers under 25 to 9% for those over 65.

column1: Many Americans of all ages have struggled to save in the last two years when inflation reached a 40-year high.
More on inflation's bite:High costs disrupt life in more ways than we can see
In the 2023 Retirement Confidence Survey
column2: conducted by the nonprofit Employee Benefit Research Institute
column3: 84% of workers voiced concern that the rising cost of living will make it harder for them to save money for retirement.

column1: An employer match may not seem like much money.
“People look at it and say
column2: ‘It’s only 3%
column3: ’” said James Gambaccini
column4: a certified financial planner in Reston
column5: Virginia. But “it’s a 100% match up to 3% of your salary.”

column1: The formula Gambaccini describes
column2: matching the employee’s full retirement contribution up to 3% of their pay
column3: would double a 3% contribution to 6% without the worker spending another dollar. An employee with a $50
column4: 000 salary would see a $1
column5: 500 contribution grow to $3

column1: “Football belongs to everybody.”
Think about those words and what they mean to you. They probably tell you how much the American version of the sport captivates the country every weekend of the fall.
But consider the source of these words: They’re from a woman
column2: a former Division I athlete but one who never really got a chance to play football.

column1: When Karissa Niehoff sees what’s going on now with the game and its opportunities for girls
column2: her mind goes back to when she was a senior in high school.

column1: “We played Powderpuff against our archrival team
column2: the archrival town and it was essentially a flag situation
column3: ” said Niehoff
column4: now the CEO of the National Federation of State High School Associations (NFHS). “But that’s all we had.”

column1: It wasn’t much
column2: a game played by girls as a kind of afterthought to the “real thing” the boys played. Several decades later
column3: though
column4: amid a broader national picture of equity
column5: it’s a sport girls are making distinctly their own.

column1: Flag football has become one of the hottest and fastest growing sports for kids to play For girls specifically
column2: though
column3: it’s one they have seized with a national wave of enthusiasm.

column1: Already soaring in popularity at the youth levels
column2: girls flag football has achieved high school varsity status in eight states (Alabama
column3: Alaska
column4: Arizona
column5: California
column6: Florida Georgia
column7: New York and Nevada) as either a fall or spring sport and 18 more states have pilot programs that could achieve that status soon. There are 15
column8: 000-plus girls playing flag football at more than 700 high schools
column9: according to the NFHS.

column1: It's a sport we learned last week will be offered for men and women at the 2028 Los Angeles Olympic Games and one the NFL is supporting with youth initiatives and grant programs to assist states in starting programs at schools.
“The collaboration behind the growth of flag is something we have never seen or been a part of to this degree
column2: ” Niehoff told USA TODAY Sports in a phone interview last week. “In terms of the pace of growth
column3: I’d be hard-pressed to say that anything has grown as quickly as flag.

column1: “I’ve just always loved football
column2: ” she says
column3: “and I think they’re a lot of women and girls that love football. And so I think an opportunity for them to enter into the sport with a more equitable kind of physical prowess
column4: playing field is really exciting.”

column1: It's also just fun. What is the allure behind this vibrant girls sport that is sweeping America? USA TODAY Sports takes a closer look:
“We’re representing our school!”
“We’re representing our family!”
“Most of all
column2: we’re representing each other!”

column1: That cheer was captured by a CBS report about a local high school flag football team in the San Francisco Bay Area.
Girls across the country are playing a sport they previously only watched their brothers play. On this team
column2: though
column3: there are two girls who watched their dad play. You may have heard of him – Hall of Fame quarterback Steve Young. He’s now an assistant coach for their team at Menlo School.

column1: Young’s two sons never played football
column2: but daughters Summer and Laila dove in head first at the chance.

column1: “I wanted to do what my dad did and feel what he felt when he was doing this sport
column2: ” says Laila
column3: a wide receiver.

column1: Likewise
column2: coaches like Young nationwide are seeing girls experience those “Ah-ha!” moments we all cherish when they throw a spiral
column3: line up for a formation or correctly follow a snap count for the first time.

column1: “They go on four
column2: no one flinched
column3: ” Young said in a local TV interview. “And I was like
column4: ‘IT took me 15 years to go on 2. We’d remind ourselves the whole way to the line of scrimmage
column5: ‘It’s two
column6: it’s two
column7: ’ and we’d still go offsides. And they get it in 15 seconds.”

column1: Girls are feeling it
column2: and loving it
column3: taking a game with which most of us are familiar and carving it into something distinctly their own.

column1: “I just had a phone call with a gentleman that coaches in North Carolina
column2: ” Niehoff told USA TODAY Sports. “Having been a coach of multiple girls sports and teams over the years
column3: he said
column4: ‘When I’ve coached boys
column5: they support one another
column6: of course
column7: but the girls cheer for one another even in practice.’ When somebody does a really good execution of a play or learns a skill
column8: he said
column9: ‘I really like how the girls engage in the camaraderie and the support really overtly.’ ”

column1: COACH STEVE: Sports parents
column2: you're out of control; behave or get off the sideline

column1: Flag is football with no hitting
column2: even in a football-crazed state in Alabama. (“NON-CONTACT SPORT
column3: ” it says in the state’s rules listed online.) It’s a sport kids can play (and parents can watch) without worrying about being leveled.

column1: But that doesn’t mean they’re not playing football. Down the California coast from Young in San Diego
column2: Drew Brees is an assistant coach with the Santa Fe Christian high school’s girls flag team. Brees
column3: another famed NFL quarterback who retired after the 2020 season
column4: is at the forefront of the flag movement
column5: co-founding the Football ’N’ America youth leagues in 2017 in New Orleans while he still played for the Saints.

column1: He didn’t put on pads until he played tackle football in high school. He learned football’s fundamentals playing flag
column2: a game of strategy and precision.

column1: As they juke and cut through defenders who swipe for their flags
column2: girls are discovering crucial components of football that aren’t always emphasized in a game built on a reputation of being rough.

column1: “The games that we don’t win
column2: we aren’t playing together as a team
column3: ” Avery Brewster
column4: a senior co-captain on Mission Viejo’s high school team in California
column5: told USA TODAY Sports. “Sometimes I’ve noticed in tackle football
column6: it’s just like a receiver throwing to one person (and) sometimes it can work because that person’s stronger but with us
column7: with flag football
column8: because we’re not tackling and we’re pulling flags
column9: we have to play together as team.

column1: “If we all don’t run our routes correctly
column2: because there’s no one blocking us
column3: then that leaves our quarterback stranded because nobody’s open. But when we work together as a team
column4: there’s always somebody that’s open when we run our routes correctly and we play better. And the chemistry is there.”

column1: COACH STEVE: Think you're a good sports parent? Coach for Tom Brady
column2: Drew Brees has radical advice for you

column1: Flag football delves deeply into a component of football we see every time we watch a video of a coach handing out a game ball. The players are gathered around as they are called out for their contributions to the game and the coach’s shoutouts are followed by hoots and hollers.

A 2018 study on teen sport in America by the Women’s Sports Foundation found that boys who participated in full-contact football had some of the highest self-esteems among youth sports participants. It’s a game where youth and high school rosters can go more than 50 deep and yet have each player make a unique contribution and feel a part of the team.
Michele LaBotz
column2: medical director of the athletic training program at the University of New England
column3: cited the study at a media briefing last week hosted by the National Athletic Trainers’ Association. Labotz
column4: though
column5: sees something else at play
column6: too.

column1: “It’ll be interesting to see how this carries over to flag football but (football is) one of the few sports that is really welcoming to the child and adolescent who’s carrying extra weight
column2: especially those that are carrying quite a bit of extra weight who really struggle with finding other opportunities for sport participation
column3: ” she says
column4: “and football sometimes is the only option that they have.”

column1: Half of the girls playing flag football in high schools across American
column2: according to the NFSA
column3: weren't even participating in other high school sports before this one came along.

column1: Yes
column2: flag football players already have role models they can emulate like Mexico quarterback Diana Flores
column3: who was featured in a commercial at the last Super Bowl in which she evades a dizzying number of defenders
column4: including broadcaster Erin Andrews and her mother.

column1: But they can also admire the girl next to them who
column2: like them
column3: is trying something new.

column1: “I just think it’s really cool that they have the opportunity to do this and feel included and feel not alone in everything
column2: ” says Katie Neilson
column3: another senior co-captain on Mission Viejo’s team in California who has only been playing the sport since her sophomore year. “We’ve all gotten really close with our teammates and it’s really cool to see girls come out of their comfort zone and feel comfortable around us.”

column1: In California
column2: where girls flag is being offered as a varsity sport for the first time this fall
column3: more than 400 schools are participating in it.

column1: Emmy Walton got a sense of the sport’s soaring popularity when she and her organization
column2: Women of Will (WoW)
column3: helped host a tournament at Mission Viejo High last month. The event drew 21 schools from four sports hotbeds in the southern part of the state: Los Angeles County
column4: Orange County
column5: the Inland Empire and San Diego.

column1: “I would have been all over flag football if it was an option for me
column2: ” says Walton
column3: a four-year varsity soccer player at Cal State Fullerton and the national account manager for Women of Will.

column1: Women of Will
column2: which partners with apparel and equipment outfits BSN Sports and Under Armour
column3: is a unique
column4: girls-only sports high school sponsorship program. It promotes women’s identities as female athletes as part of a nationwide network that has reached 300-plus schools in almost every stae.

column1: WoW celebrates women's sports through uniform designs but also hypes the players who wear them
column2: hosting days at high schools where girls teams are championed like boys football on homecoming.

column1: “When we grew up
column2: there wasn’t even girls athletic wear
column3: ” Walton says. “There wasn’t girls soccer shirts. It was all just like boys
column4: and it was all baggy and everything. Luckily
column5: we’ve got a big highlight and spotlight on females in sport now and we’ve got amazing gear that actually fits our bodies. …

column1: “Part of the Women of Will program is trying to help build female programs
column2: female teams
column3: getting more girls to try out
column4: especially after COVID
column5: (when) we saw a huge decline in sport participation. ... I can’t imagine not having the experiences and the life lessons I learned from playing sports.

column1: “We want to give them something that will leave a legacy of empowering female athletes in creating a culture change on campus of these ladies having a safe space to rise up as leaders.”
It’s been about 20 years since Walton played prep sports. When she walks around a high school campus these days
column2: she gets a much different picture than the one once saw through teenaged eyes.

column1: Students pass her with their heads down or their ears plugged with wireless earpieces. Some of them don’t talk even to the people they pass and see.
Then Walton goes out to the athletic fields or into the gymnasiums. There
column2: the communication is as vibrant as ever. She sees girls like she once was with sense of direction
column3: spirit and purpose. She sees something else
column4: too.

column1: They’re playing football.
“These girls can be pioneers
column2: ” she says. “I hope that colleges are seeing how fast this sport is growing and how important it is to offer it.”

column1: With each passing year
column2: Niehoff
column3: the NFHS’ CEO
column4: guesses two to four states will sanction girls flag as a varsity sport. NAIA schools and junior colleges are already offering scholarships for it. Niehoff fully expects the sport to become a Division 1 opportunity to women down the road.

column1: “I think what flag will do for the football in general is have better conversations at the dinner table when Mom or Dad has their child say
column2: ‘I want to play football
column3: ’ ” she says. “By getting kids excited about flag
column4: they get excited about football … We’re getting families to embrace the sport of football with a different lens.”

column1: After all
column2: as she knows
column3: football belongs to everybody.

column1: Steve Borelli
column2: aka Coach Steve
column3: has been an editor and writer with USA TODAY since 1999. He spent 10 years coaching his two sons’ baseball and basketball teams. He and his wife
column4: Colleen
column5: are now sports parents for a high schooler and middle schooler. His column is posted weekly. For his past columns
column6: click here.

column1: Got a question for Coach Steve you want answered in a column? Email him at sborelli@usatoday.com
The best advice you can give a college coach is to change jobs every seven or eight years
column2: if they’re lucky enough to make it that long. It doesn’t apply in every case
column3: of course. There’s a separate category for coaches who win national championships
column4: though they aren’t necessarily immune either. Coaches who regularly punch above their weight at programs that don't expect titles might have it best of all in this business because they can usually stay as long as they want.

column1: But if you're at a top-shelf place and you’re good but constantly falling short of the ultimate goal in the same way over and over again
column2: you’re always on a timer. Even if the school doesn’t really want to fire you
column3: the fans eventually tire of you. And even with all the money being deposited in your bank account
column4: it’s not the best quality of life.

column1: Meet James Franklin
column2: the coach at Penn State. He’s had some good stretches. He’s had a few down periods. But mainly
column3: he’s just kind of achieved at the same level for 10 years. And that level isn’t Ohio State or Michigan's level
column4: which means the Nittany Lions have been cut out of the College Football Playoff picture because of two teams they play every year.

column1: Is that good enough? Penn State needs to beat those teams now and then. And Saturday seemed like a good chance
column2: with Ohio State somewhat diminished from the offensive monster they were the last few years and Penn State sporting the best defense it’s had under Franklin. This year might have been as even as the overall talent has ever been.

column1: And for all that
column2: Franklin’s team didn’t even really show up. Yeah
column3: they were in the game into the fourth quarter. But they didn’t play well at all offensively
column4: gaining just 240 yards with 49 rushing yards on 26 attempts.

column1: In the end
column2: it was a 20-12 loss with a garbage time touchdown making it look more respectable
column3: dropping Franklin to 1-9 against Ohio State. He’s fared better against Michigan (3-6)
column4: but the Wolverines weren’t a top-10 team in those three good years.

column1: In other words
column2: the overall picture is more or less the same for Penn State as it was six or seven years ago once Franklin got the program rolling. Whether they’re right or wrong
column3: how long until the people at Penn State just want something … different?

column1: The romance in college football is often in the hope and the unknown
column2: but that’s gone at Penn State. They know what the program is and isn’t under Franklin. At this point
column3: fans could probably predict almost word-for-word what he’s going to say at his press conference.

column1: And it’s all really good. But as Saturday’s performance showed
column2: still not good enough.

column1: For that reason
column2: Penn State is No. 1 in this week’s Misery Index
column3: a weekly measurement of which fan bases are feeling the most angst about the state of their favorite program.

column1: In the euphoria of Sam Pittman getting the Razorbacks to 9-4 in 2021
column2: the athletics director at Arkansas did what ADs usually do in these situations. He got hoodwinked by super agent Jimmy Sexton into giving out a big contract extension
column3: even though Pittman was neither leaving nor being seriously pursued by anyone else. That AD’s name is Hunter Yurachek
column4: and these days you mostly hear about him because he’s been one of the loudest voices begging for a national law regulating name
column5: image and likeness and arguing that schools will go broke or have to cut sports if players become employees and get paid.

column1: But when Yurachek has to fire his football coach -- which might be this year -- you won't hear him cry poor or threaten to pull money from women’s volleyball or men’s golf. He’ll just go find the money because that’s what these ADs do. And it’ll be a lot of money — either $16.1 million or $10.7 million
column2: which is an interesting story on its own.

column1: The contract stipulated that Pittman got an extra year if he won seven games at any point in the deal
column2: which was accomplished last season when the Razorbacks went 7-6. But if his overall record dipped from the beginning of 2021 dipped below .500 it would be a smaller buyout.

column1: After a 7-3 loss to Mississippi State — Arkansas’ sixth in a row and 10th in its last 12 SEC games — Pittman’s record since 2021 is 18-16. If the Hogs lose their next two to Florida and Auburn
column2: he’ll be right at .500 heading into a Nov. 18 game against…Florida International.

column1: It’s all funny money these days in college football
column2: but the idea that a game against FIU could be worth $5.4 million to Pittman personally and to Arkansas’ budget is maybe the only funny thing about this disaster of a Razorbacks season.

column1: One of many schools that got tricked into thinking they really had something going during the bizarro pandemic season of 2020

column3: 2 1/2 seasons and a measly eight total wins later
column4: Indiana would be on the hook for a $20 million buyout if they want to get rid of him.

column1: And they probably need to after dropping to 2-5 overall and 0-4 in the Big Ten with a 31-14 loss to Rutgers.
Hey
column2: Indiana fans had reason to be excited back then. Indiana wasn’t a one-hit COVID wonder
column3: but it was a two-hit wonder under Allen. In 2019
column4: when the Hoosiers went 8-5
column5: their offensive coordinator was Kalen DeBoer
column6: who has worked wonders at Fresno State and now Washington. Their defensive coordinator was Kane Wommack
column7: an up-and-comer who is winning big at South Alabama. By 2021
column8: both were gone — as is quarterback Michael Penix who tore it up in 2020
column9: suffered from multiple injuries and ultimately followed DeBoer to the Huskies
column10: where he is now the Heisman Trophy favorite.

column1: So while Allen obviously had something to do with the success
column2: he totally owns the failure that has followed. Indiana is a football program used to going back to square one every few years. It seems they're about to find themselves back in the same spot.

column1: Here’s the state of things currently in East Lansing. On the night they lost at home 49-0 to their most hated rival with an interim coach who is in place because their old coach admitted to masturbating on the phone with a university vendor who subsequently filed a sexual harassment complaint
column2: somehow the only thing anyone will remember about this game is Adolf Hitler. We shouldn’t have to explain why it’s bad to have an image of a smiling Hitler on your scoreboard as part of your pre-game entertainment
column3: regardless of context. (It was a trivia question that the university apologized for and blamed on poor oversight of a third-party vendor.) But how did that one slip past the game operations people? Or
column4: as soon as somebody saw anything involving Hitler on the scoreboard
column5: how did someone not just reach as quickly as possible for the button to turn it off? But however it happened
column6: unspeakable embarrassment keeps coming for the Spartans.

column1: It’s very hard to get to the national championship game. It’s almost as hard to throw away most of that goodwill with the fan base in a matter of 10 months. But that’s about where the Horned Frogs find themselves after a 41-3 loss at Kansas State. At 4-4 with trips to Texas Tech and Oklahoma still on the schedule along with home games against Texas and Baylor
column2: it will be a high-wire act for Sonny Dykes to get this very mediocre team to 6-6. TCU was obviously an excellent team last year with Max Duggan at quarterback
column3: but also had a lot of good bounces go its way. If a Duggan-less TCU follows that up with a losing record
column4: that run might be remembered as a bit of a historical fluke.

column1: Somehow
column2: despite being a dog-tired football team
column3: the Knights managed to score on a fourth-and-10 with 1:16 remaining to pull within a two-point conversion of tying Oklahoma in Norman. And then what did they do? They tried a terrible
column4: double-pass trick play that required the ball to go seven yards behind the line of scrimmage before a right-handed receiver rolled left. Meanwhile

column6: UCF fans. And remarkably

column1: Shane Beamer had an unexpectedly fun first two years with the Gamecocks. But he’s getting a reputation as the saltiest loser in the sport

column4: he kicked a Gatorate cooler and broke a bone in his foot. And even after Saturday's 34-12 loss at Missouri
column5: he made a snide comment about the press conference room being sub-standard compared to the school's nice new facilities. Is this stuff a huge deal? No. And Beamer is a nice guy

column1: Welcome to the big time
column2: Bearkats. And no
column3: we don't mean Conference USA. We mean the Misery Index

column5: you for some reason decided to leave that comfort zone and jump on the FBS train. And after a 33-27 double-overtime loss to Florida International
column6: you now know how hard it's going to be. Sam Houston State is now 0-7 since moving up

column8: possible player compensation and a widening gap between the haves and have-nots
column9: how much upside was there really for you to make this move?

column1: The trajectory seemed clear
column2: from complete despair to signs of life to winning records in 2021 and 2022. But suddenly

column1: Sebastian Cook is pursuing his dream of becoming a barber. Some days
column2: he spends up to 12 hours at the Brevard-based academy he attends. With a rule passed Wednesday by the Florida Board of Education
column3: the 19-year-old transgender man will be barred from accessing a bathroom he feels comfortable using.

column1: It makes me really terrified to go to school, he said. "I am not a woman. I don't look like a woman. More women will be uncomfortable with me in their restroom when most men don't even realize I'm trans when I use the restroom."
More than 19 million Americans joined an international earthquake drill on Thursday that encouraged people to drop
column2: cover and hold on
column3: a planned event that happened just a day after a quake rattled northern California.

column1: But millions more are at risk
column2: said Mark Benthien
column3: global ShakeOut coordinator and outreach director for the Southern California Earthquake Center at the University of Southern California.

column1: The chances of an earthquake somewhere around the world are 100% every day
column2: Benthien said.

column1: The Earth often shakes the ground across the nation and its territories. Hillsborough
column2: North Carolina felt an earthquake on Thursday
column3: according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

column1: That North Carolina quake was one of more than 150 earthquakes of at least a 2.0 magnitude across the continental United States in 19 states over the past week. At least 34 earthquakes of a 2.5 magnitude or higher occurred in Puerto Rico
column2: 30 in Alaska and 10 in Hawaii in the last seven days.

column1: No. Should you prepare? Absolutely. Earthquakes can occur anywhere in the country
column2: although they are less frequent in some places.

column1: “People need to know and practice what to do
column2: ” said Benthien.

column1: We're trying to get people to be more self-sufficient, because in a big earthquake there’s not going to be help from the neighboring city, he said. “They’re going to be impacted too.”
And when a big one occurs
column2: it’s likely to trigger others around it.

column1: It may seem like it
column2: but that's because we’ve seen dramatic improvement in the quantity and quality of equipment that records seismic activity in the Earth
column3: Benthien said. We “have the ability to record smaller and smaller earthquakes
column4: ” not just in California
column5: but in distant locations where there aren’t any people
column6: and even under the seafloor.

column1: In some respects
column2: we owe improvements in earthquake forecasting to the Cold War
column3: Benthien said. Seismometers were established in far-flung locations across the world as the U.S.
column4: Russia and China tried to monitor whether the others were conducting underground nuclear tests. As a college student
column5: he once worked along a fault in Siberia and Mongolia.

column1: Apps alert phones when shaking is detected and social media also has contributed to the more frequent communication of earthquakes. “People are feeling small earthquakes and posting about it
column2: ” he said. “So it seems like there’s a lot more earthquakes happening
column3: but it’s because there’s a lot more earthquake information happening and happening more frequently.”

column1: It’s normal for seismic activity to temporarily increase or decrease
column2: and neither positively indicates a large earthquake is eminent
column3: according to the geological survey.

column1: The earthquake risk is growing
column2: because of increasing human and economic exposure and the number of assets being built in high earthquake hazard areas
column3: the Federal Emergency Management Agency said in a report earlier this year.

column1: Although Alaska is the most seismically active state in the U.S.
column2: the risks and potential impacts are greater in California because it has the highest estimated potential loss due to earthquakes
column3: according to the geological survey.

column1: The Earth’s crust is like the shell of an egg. It’s very thin compared to the planet. Like the shell of a hard-boiled egg breaks into pieces when you crack it
column2: the earth’s crust is broken into large pieces or plates and those plates move around
column3: Benthien said.

column1: The Pacific plate moves to the northwest at a speed of 3-4 inches a year
column2: while the North American plate moves to the west-southwest at about an inch a year
column3: according to the Pacific Northwest Seismic Network. The motion of the plates around the globe is the primary source of strain that leads to earthquakes.

column1: Major quakes are often preceded by smaller quakes
column2: foreshocks
column3: and followed by additional quakes
column4: aftershocks
column5: which can also be quite large.

column1: Earthquakes often occur in groups of mostly small earthquakes with no identifiable mainshock
column2: according to the geological survey. These groups are called clusters or swarms

column5: a spokesman for the geological survey.

column1: A group of researchers at the University of Utah are studying the swarms of earthquakes that occur there. Many of the frequent earthquakes in the region are small
column2: happening imperceptibly
column3: but in surges
column4: clustered in time and space
column5: researchers Gesa Petersen and Kristine Pankow stated in a study published in July.

column1: The “seismic groups” strike a region over a short period of time and dozens have been recorded in Central Utah over 40 years. As many as 30
column2: 40 or 50 events occur over a few hours and then it pauses. That occurs repeatedly
column3: the researchers said.

column1: Of all the sequences of seismic activity in the region
column2: 80% are swarms
column3: the researchers said. The university’s seismologists are analyzing that data to try to determine their significance.

column1: A 9.0 or larger earthquake would only occur along a subduction zone
column2: Benthien said. Those occur chiefly in coastal regions where an oceanic plate in the earth’s crust meets a continental plate along a tectonic plate boundary and slides beneath it.

column1: One subduction zone occurs in Alaska
column2: where a 9.2 earthquake shook the Prince William Sound region in 1964. It remains the most powerful on record in North America. The quake and the resulting tsunami killed 131 people. A peak wave height of roughly 219 feet occurred at Valdez Inlet and waves were detected on tide gages as far away as Cuba and Puerto Rico.

column1: Subduction zones occur around the Pacific
column2: in an area sometimes called the "Ring of Fire" for its earthquakes and volcanic eruptions. It includes the Pacific Northwest
column3: the area of the U.S. at greatest risk
column4: and the west coast of South America
column5: where the largest recorded earthquake in the world – 9.5 – occurred in Chile on May 22

The USA TODAY Opinion section publishes analysis
column2: argument and essays on a wide variety of subjects. We're looking for timeliness (pegged to news)
column3: persuasion pitched to the other side
column4: new information
column5: novel arguments
column6: revelatory insights
column7: passion without partisanship
column8: first-person experience
column9: original reporting that reveals fresh angles and makes news
column10: expert knowledge
column11: and/or a topic that will drive conversation on social media and in the real world.

column1: We accept only pieces that are submitted exclusively to USA TODAY. We do not accept material that has been published on blogs
column2: social media or anywhere else.

column1: Columns typically run 550 to 750 words. They should be pasted directly into an email and sent to theforum@usatoday.com. Pieces should include links (URLs
column2: not headlines or footnotes) to back up quotes and factual material. People featured in columns must be identified by their real
column3: full names.

column1: We do not publish open letters
column2: class projects or material that has been submitted to multiple outlets. Rebuttals to editorials and columns published in USA TODAY should be submitted as letters to the editor
column3: not as full-length op-eds.

column1: Due to the volume of submissions
column2: we can’t respond to all columns sent to us. If our Opinion team is interested in yours
column3: you will hear from us within three business days.

column1: Submissions may be edited for accuracy
column2: clarity
column3: style
column4: standards and length.

column1: Please include with your submission a short biography
column2: two sentences at most
column3: to run at the end of your column
column4: as well as a current photograph
column5: to which you own publishing rights. If you or a business
column6: trade group or other institution with which you are associated stands to gain financially or in any other way from your column
column7: you should disclose that information in detail. In most cases
column8: it should also be included in the body of the piece or in the author's biographical information.

column1: Columns are accepted for online publication; print publication is not guaranteed. All columns published by USA TODAY are available for use online and in print by the more than 250 properties in the USA TODAY Network. They include Austin; Bergen County

column1: Authors may post their columns elsewhere 48 hours after they are published at USA TODAY. By submitting a column to USA TODAY and agreeing to its publication
column2: authors are granting exclusive rights to the piece to the USA TODAY Network for 48 hours and non-exclusive rights thereafter.

column1: Letters are edited for accuracy
